39425541.review:
So you're wondering what the deal is with this game, you're thinking because it's in Early Access it probably won't be finished and the entry fee is too high. Look i get it, I'd be wary too but let me reassure you of a few things before you make any rash decisions.

For starters you're already getting 65%-75% of the product, all that's remaining is the final 3rd episode consisting of 11 levels, additional endless mode arena and a solid build of DuskWorld multi-player which is currently available in it's beta stage. That's not all either, Dusk will launch with achievements, trading cards and leaderboards as well!

Consider this, if you purchase the game in it's current state you could very well be helping with the funding of future content and maybe even a sequel? who knows! I know I'd be down for one. There are already plans for post launch which include a co-op mode, an SDK and Steam Workshop functionality. We could possibly even see some mission packs, who doesn't like mission packs?!

Now as to the existing content? it's fun as hell and totally nails the look and feel of a mid-90's FPS. With polygonal models, full 3D handcrafted level design and a killer soundtrack you'll feel transported back to a time before warfare was modern and your health never regenerated. Dusk is absolutely a love letter to Quake mixed with some Blood and Redneck Rampage aesthetics. All the hallmarks you've come to expect from a retro shooter are right here!

You want an assortment of badass weaponry? you got'em!
You want key cards? you got 'em
You want secrets? you got'em!
You want power-ups? you got'em!

This isn't some rogue-like procedurally generated nonsense. It's the real deal!

So what are you waiting for? It's time to lock and load and get your frag on.

DOPEFISH LIVES!

39422178.review:
This is the game I've been waiting for ever since Devil Daggers rekindled my love for fast FPS. The level design would make golden era Id software proud, huge semi abstract spaces with secrets everywhere. It's not just a carbon copy of Quake either, there are nods to modern games (Superhot! Doom 2016!) and a rudimentary physics engine that is very useful both in combat and exploration.
It's also very polished for an early accessed title, with very few bugs. The only downside is we're still waiting for the final act and it's a bit on the short side right now.

39410562.review:
Dusk is an amazing game, if you love classics like Doom and Quake you need to try Dusk. In the past few years many have released games that they claim to be classic retro shooters but they ended up being a shoot-a-thon where you fight hordes of endless enemies that run at you with very basic AI.

Classic shooters weren’t about that at all, yes they are fast paced and you fight a lot of enemies but you also had genius enemy placement and level design. Each enemy has its own AI and they fill a specific role and provide a different challenge. Dusk delivers in all of this. Something that also made these games so memorable are the guns, they feel satisfying and fill a specific role, again, Dusk does it pretty well, the guns are refined and balanced to the point of never being obsolete no matter where you are in the game. Get this gem if you are a fan of classic shooters, you will not be disappointed, the price is an absolute steal, get it now.

39408180.review:
[h1][b]Dusk combines all the great elements of games from the past into a modern masterpiece that has the asthetic of an ancient masterpiece.[/b][/h1]

[h1][b]About The Game:[/b][/h1]
Dusk is a First Person Retro Shooter developed by David Szymanski & published by New Blood Interactive, it is a modern take on the retro shooter genre. No story, no over the top action cinematics, not very much dialogue & most importantly no taking away the players control for a terrible scripted event.

Dusk takes a lot of inspiration from old time classics like Wolfenstein, DOOM, Blood & Duke Nukem, you now have Dusk! There's barely any variation from these influences, it feels exactly like these games did but in a more modernised attempt at recreating them.

Dusk has everything from these old classic titles such as easter eggs to old time movies & video games, references from old movies & video games, good ol' classic old school FPS fast paced action & a plethora of different hidden secrets scattered throughout the maps with lots of goodies in them if you can find them all!

[h1][b]The Gameplay:[/b][/h1]
Gameplay from Dusk is simple, you are an unnamed person, out to kill a bunch of different enemies which have really no background. You are there to kill them just because they stand in your way. There's small snippets of story in between chapters but just like in DOOM it's few and far between and only gives you a very minor amount of detail as to what you're doing there and why.

The game starts you off right in the deep end (just like DOOM did all those years ago) putting you in a dark cave, with no explaination as to why, you have got 3 chainsaw weilding maniacs running at you and you've gotta fend them off with only your Sickles.

Throughout each of the maps there's many hidden places for you to hunt down & unlock, each of them contains something to aid the player throughout the campaign, whether it be a weapon, ammo, armour, a heath item or (of course) hidden powerups that give the player temporary buffs. Some of these hidden places contain subtle hints to old time classic video game titles & movies. (If you were a gamer in the 90's or a movie watcher in the 80's you'll pick up these right away.)

While Dusk takes heavy inspiration from 90's shooters it also has it's own modern gameplay mechanics too. Players can utilize the environment as weapons, for example if a player picks up an item such as a saw blade you can then hurl this & other items at an enemy and it will practically insta gib them, you also have an option to weapon zoom to take pot shots at distant enemies, jump & crouch, etc.

There's just so much to love about the gameplay of this game that I could talk about it for ages, however it's time to move on.

[h1][b]The Verdict:[/b][/h1]
Dusk is a fantastic attempt at recreating the feel of a classic FPS game but giving the game it's own flavour & of course matching modern mechanics with classic mechanics.

There's so much that Dusk gets correct, everything from the feel of the game to the asthetic of it is perfect. The game looks great & has many customizable options to make it looks more retro, if you're not happy enough with the retro look you can go super retro with filters that give the game more jaggies, turn off mouse look, and even different colour tones if you want it darker, lighter, monotone, etc. The player tailoring customizations are incredible.

Dusk gets an A for effort in its attempt at recreating the feel, look and gameplay of classic FPS shooters from yester year, it gets a lot right & honestly I haven't really got any gripes with the game. The only thing I can REALLY say that I have a gripe with is that sometimes some of the secrets feel like they're a bit rushed & just placed in the map because they needed to fill their secret quota. (Sometimes you'll come across a secret within a secret too often.)

[h1][b]Recommendation?:[/b][/h1]
So with ALL that I've said can I recommend this game? It's safe for me to say I can easily recommend this game, 

I'm having a blast with Dusk & I can't say that I regret buying this title at all. I love these kinds of games & I think I'll be coming back to Dusk quite a lot in the future!

[h1][b]Closing Remarks:[/b][/h1]
Only a few things I can say here and those would be, I hope that the developer keeps on releasing content for this game in the future or gives the community the ability to create user content (Just like Quake & DOOM did) so that this game continues to thrive for years to come. If DOOM can be released in 1993 & STILL be active with a very strong community then this game can be the same in 20 years time with the right commitments from the community & developer alike.

Keep up the awesome work David, really hope to see more of these kinds of games from you in the future!

39379158.review:
Over the past few years, we here on Steam have seen several developers make games that they boldly claim are "90s FPS throwbacks," only to be severely disappointed and left shaking our heads (for the most part; there are some exceptions out there, but they are sadly few and far between).

DUSK is NOT one of those disappointments; not even remotely close. As a seasoned veteran of the 90s FPS genre, with games such as *inhales deeply* Doom, Doom II, Duke Nukem 3D: Atomic Edition, all of Duke's expansions, Shadow Warrior, all of SW's expansions, Blood, Final Doom (both TNT and Plutonia), Quake, Quake II, Heretic, Hexen, Hexen: Deathkings of the Dark Citadel, Unreal Gold, Half-Life, Half-Life 2 and probably some others that I'm forgetting *exhales* I can say that this game without a doubt brings back that sweet, sumptuous feel of classic, fast-paced shooter action we FPS vets have been so dreaming of since that golden era came and went.

Starting with the devs themselves; while I have not met them personally, I have seen interviews with them (a group of anywhere between 3-6 people I believe is correct), and heard testimonies of those who have met them, and they sound like a right fine group of people: Extremely responsive and talkative with their fans and fellow 90s shooter fanatics, open to criticism and have an extremely sarcastic sense of humor at times. Always a plus to see devs that care as much about the community as they do about their product.

Now, onto the game. Similar to Doom, DUSK is being released episodically. If you pre-ordered the game before Christmas last year, you got the first episode, The Foothills, along with Endless Arena 1, a small arena where you face a never-ending swarm of baddies until you are killed (called The Farm I think). Recently, New Blood Interactive released the second episode, The Facilities, which is leaps and bounds superior to the first episode in terms of level design and overall fun factor...NOT to say that Episode 1 was bad by any means, but after playing through Episode 2, it becomes clear that the level design has been worked on quite considerably. Every level feels different, visceral and some even horrifying. To add one last note here, per NBI's entry on the game's store page, if you pre-ordered the game before Christmas, you will also get a FREE UPGRADE to the Digital Deluxe Edition, which will include the full OST along with a digital comic!

The weapons? Just what you'd expect from a game such as this; a pistol which can be wielded akimbo once you find a second one, a Winchester 1887-esque lever-action shotgun which can also be wielded akimbo once you find another one (which looks and sounds SO SATISFYING to use by the way), a Super Shotgun a la Doom II and Quake, so on and so forth, an Assault Rifle (which to me looks more like an LMG of some sort, but I split hairs), a pair of scythes and a magical halberd-style sword which function as your melee weapons (including a nifty, super-powerful special attack from the sword if you have 100 or more HP), a Hunting Rifle which has a nice zoom and is devastating if accurately fired (protip: you may not have used the HR too much in Episode 1...you WILL change that in Episode 2...use it against the Welders), a Heretic-inspired Crossbow which fires penetrating, phallically-shaped, glowing, green arrows at enemies which can be shot through walls and other enemies, giving the potential for massive chain kills if enemies are lined up correctly, a Mortar with grenades that, while slow, can be remotely detonated with the RMB, and the Riveter, this game's homage to the Rocket Launcher of old, which fires metallic, explosive-tipped rivets with a very satisfying metallic "clank" noise and can absolutely DEVASTATE bosses and crowds of weaker baddies. Also, a cigar which you can smoke to slowly regenerate your health, because why not, right?

The enemies? Just as varied as the weapons. Weaker enemies at first, followed by bigger, badder ones (especially in the second episode), and even a fair amount of boss battles to add a little varied spice to the game. The Riveter will make short work of just about any of them.

The music? Ohhhhhhhhhh my goodness, the music...Andrew Hulshult is a video game music GENIUS. Tracks can vary from outright spooky to headbangingly metal. Seriously, play E2M6 (The Erebus Reactor) at your own risk...if you're anything like me, you'll be too busy jamming to the most deliciously metal track you've ever heard in a video game to focus on gunning down the massive room full of enemies and might find yourself stupidly getting killed a couple to few times because of it. NO SHAME! OST must be released NOW!

So, to summarize, while not perfect, this game is probably as close to a TRUE 90s FPS throwback as we're going to see for quite a while (and New Blood are publishing another, more Hexen/Heretic-inspired shooter as well called Amid Evil which I am definitely keeping on my wishlist!), and I cannot wait for the third episode, The Nameless City (Quake I reference!) to come out, along with the fully-developed multiplayer...and to top it all off, NBI even said they will have DEDICATED SERVERS, MAH BOIS!

If you are in any way a fan of the classic FPS genre (Doom, Quake, etc., but mostly Quake due to the fast-paced bunnyhopping you can easily do), then you will absolutely not regret getting this game; I can't recommend it enough!

Oh, and one last thing? There's a bar of soap in this game that you can throw at enemies...FEAR THE SOAP!*

*Because it does TEN MILLION points of damage, according to the Dusk Wiki. Ten. Million. Bosses beware. Duskdude is coming for you with the dreaded SOAP!

39369994.review:
プレイ状況：エピソード1と2をCero Miedo(2つめに高い難易度で被ダメージと敵の速度がアップ、最高難易度のDuskmareは敵の攻撃が即死ダメージになる)でクリア。

正しくクラシックFPSしてるFPS。正確にはQuakeとBloodをあわせた見た目・雰囲気にPainkillerばりのバニーホップ前提のガンプレイ。

・武器バランスはよい感じで、序盤は貧弱なピストルでも二挺装備をすれば雑魚相手に有用な遠距離武器になるし、SSGの爽快感と破壊力も合格点。最終武器であるリベッターもものすごく強い。殆どネタアイテムとして葉巻も用意されている。
・敵の移動スピードと攻撃速度はかなり速く、被ダメージも大きいので、とにかく動き回ってあたらないようにするのが重要。この辺もクラシックFPSらしいスタイルである。
・パワーアップは短時間攻撃速度アップのヘイスト、自由に壁をよじ登れるクライミングギア、SUPERHOT状態(動いてない間ほぼ時間停止)になるアドレナリン?、溶岩ダメージを無効化する防護スーツを確認。進行の都合上クライミングギアはリスポーンする(防護スーツは未確認)。
・グラフィックはスクリーンショットを見てのとおりQuake 1風味の強いローポリとなっているが、エフェクト周りはそれなりにがんばっている。
・マップデザインはプレイした範囲ではやや複雑(Redneck Rampageほどではない)で迷いやすいほうか。シークレットを巧妙に隠した配置であり、レベル間で武器が持ち越せない"Intruder Mode"でも遊べるよう武器もバランスよく配置されている。
・マップはエピソード1と2、どちらも10マップ+シークレット1つの構成となっており、一度クリアすればレベルセレクトで難易度と初期装備を自由に変えて再挑戦することができる。
・クラシックFPSらしくない要素だが、マップ上にあるオブジェクトの多くは持ち上げて投げることができる。ポリタンクやドラム缶、[b]石鹸[/b]がかなり有用だったりするし、箱や岩を足場にしないと届かないシークレットもある。
・マップ内のオブジェクトは持ち上げられる小型のものだけでなく、木々やガラス窓、ひび割れた壁など破壊できるものがたくさん用意されており、この辺はHexen 2やSiNあたりを思い出させる。
・シングルプレイ以外のモードはエンドレスサバイバルと対戦(Duskworld)がある。
・実績は正式リリース版で実装予定だが、レベルごとに「ノーダメージクリアのUntouchable」「キル・シークレット100%のCompletionist」「自分の手でキルせずクリアするPacifist」「近接武器とオブジェクト投げのみでクリアするLow-Tech」のアワードが用意されている。

現状での問題点はこの辺か。
・オートセーブが無いので、クイックセーブのみに頼るとつらい目にあう。
・全体的にマップは暗め。幸いにも無限に使えるフラッシュライトが用意されている(ただし特定のシーンで壊れるがすぐ再使用可能になる)し、敵やアイテムも見やすいほうである。
・総じて敵が強くて面倒。特にSSG装備のカカシ、ダメージを受けるまで完全透明なウェンディゴ、最強装備であるリベッターを3連射する女サイボーグあたりが強敵。

正式版ではエピソード３とCoopが実装予定となっているため、その辺にも期待。

39368313.review:
"KILL THE INTRUDER!"

DUSK ist ein Faced Paced First Person Shooter alla Doom, Hexen, Heretic, Quake etc.

Die Grafik ist gewollt schlecht. Sie läuft auf der Unity Engine und mal ganz ehrlich, in diesem Spiel geht es nicht um die Grafik sondern ums Gameplay welches einfach unfassbar fantastisch ist.

Das Gameplay erinnert stark an die oben genannten Titel (Bunnyhopping, Rocketjumps inclusive!). Das Spiel bietet wie bei Doom oder Quake etc. 3 Episoden (Early Acess Version Episode 1 + 2), ein sehr gelungenen Multiplayer namens "Duskworld" und 2 verschiedene Endless Modes. 39365793.review:
[h1]分量满满的复古B级杀戮秀[/h1]

首先很肯定的说，这是一款复古的fps作品。
这里的复古可不是DOOM和德军总部的那种重启，而是彻头彻尾的复古----像素画面，数字显示的血量值，快的不像话的主角移速，人肉军火库，成吨的怪物，不停的移动射击，迷宫一样的找路体验...
也许看到这里你会说，这破游戏还需要玩？古董就应该陈列在博物馆里。

打个比方，如果说英雄萨姆3，德军总部，doom这类新技术旧内核的作品像是精美的，经过了多少道工序烤制而成，不仅精致且口感颇佳的烤翅。那么这部DUSK更像是街边摊味道扑鼻，在略显简陋的盘子里滋滋冒油，伴随着吆喝声给你一份份的呈上来，每一口都是满满的幸福和惊喜的红木大串。
此外，这部游戏主要制作人只有一个--David Szymanski，他此前制作的大多为步行模拟游戏（我个人是他的粉丝，他的steamID是jefequeso，作者本人就是个老派FPS的爱好者），例如Moon Sliver，The Music Machine等大多数有着非常奇诡的风格和阴暗的剧情。所以在这部作品中他的个人风格也得到了充分的体现，可以说是在这盘过瘾的烧烤上加上了自己的独特作料（血红色的天空，枯树，非常有风格的解密要素）。

详细点说，游戏的画面尽管复古但是丝毫不影响其表现力，完全可以和迈阿密热线相媲美。阴沉压抑的地牢，危机四伏的农场都能让你惊叹复古也可以如此浪漫！
作为FPS，枪械手感自然是重中之重，从手枪到火箭筒的打击感非常畅快，配合主角的高速移动可以让你开每一枪都能获得极大满足。
音乐方面，整个游戏只有两种风格的配乐，除了压抑阴沉，就是燃爆的另类金属。作为金属迷，自然是照单全收听都听不够（详情见预告片），但金属真的不适合所有人，小心被劝退。
最后要称赞的是难度不高但是需要一定方向感的地图和关卡设计，难度有但不是很高，其解谜难度和迷宫程度与半条命系列相仿，甚至在某些场景都能看到半条命1的影子，惧怕迷路的玩家完全可以试一试。
剧情就不剧透了，反正很DOOM就是了...

总的来讲是一部非常硬派的复古FPS，游戏尚处在EA阶段，因为第三章还没有做完。所以这基本上就是一款看了预告片你就可以了解到是不是会喜欢的游戏，在这里个人很推荐，但是一定要入前看预告片！

优点：
+复古但极具风格的画面表现力
+燃爆的重金属配乐
+优秀的枪械手感
+复古的关卡设计
+硬派的游戏风格

缺点：
-流程太短
-部分解密拖慢了游戏节奏
-价格略高

一部带着旧时代B级片的Cult和血腥味的复古FPS，如果你喜欢英雄萨姆这样疯狂的射击游戏，毫不犹豫就入了吧！

39363592.review:
Dusk is a worthy descendant of the great FPS games of the 90s like Doom and Quake.

The single player has two episodes (with a third incoming), each including 10 levels with one secret level. The gameplay involves exploring maze-like levels finding health and armor pickups, weapons, ammo, and of course enemies to use them on. Although the gameplay is most similar to Quake or Doom, the combat also feels a bit like Painkiller, perhaps due to the aesthetics and open arenas you occasionally battle big groups of enemies in. The game doesn't lock you into arenas you can't escape like that game does, though: you're usually free to retreat and lure your enemies into a choke point and mow them down as they come through, if that's your thing.

There are no hitscanning enemies, so those who hated for example the chaingunners in Doom 2 can breathe a sigh of relief. Enemies' projectiles can be dodged easily by circle strafing, but being surrounded can be deadly: combat on higher difficulties is quite demanding.

Dusk includes interactive environments akin to Duke Nukem 3D and some humorous superfluous features such as spinning your weapons, eating food, activating sinks, toilets and showers or smoking a cigar. Try throwing the soap at your enemies, if you can find it.

The multiplayer is enjoyable, but it could be a bit of a brutal experience for a new player, as is generally the case in older FPS games. If you don't mind dying a lot, you'll like it.

In conclusion: if you enjoy classic 90s FPS games, you'll surely like Dusk as well. If this is not the case, this game isn't likely to change your mind, but it's worth a shot regardless in my opinion.

39361348.review:
The game is overrated but far from bad. I think people tend to forget what top-tier FPS games should actually be like after playing years and years of derivative "cinematic" and open world shooters. From a purely mechanical standpoint, it's flawless, and the weapons and enemies are some of the best I've seen in a shooter like this.

That being said, the level design can get pretty horrendous at times. Like Doom 2 Downtown levels of bad. Many levels in this game don't capitalize on verticality like games like Quake did. One of the maps is even a maze in a mineshaft, with zero landmarks, which was hell for me to get around and complete, and was annoying as hell attempting to evade enemy attacks in the tight corridors.

Many dark areas that require the flashlight are also a big issue. I don't know why this game needs the flashlight mechanic in the first place. There are plenty of shooters with dark atmosphere that don't need pitch black areas that require the use of equipment. It's just annoying, and can be a nightmare if you bring the FOV up as much as I did, which reduces the radius of your flashlight dramatically and makes it near impossible to see.

The core of a lot of these levels are essentially large fields with houses dotted around the map for you to run in between to grab keys and whatnot from. Many of these houses are designed realistically rather than something that would be good for a game with this kind of movement system. So half the time you'll be awkwardly strafejumping around the map and the other half you'll be going from generic room to generic room for enemies, weapons, and keys. The environment itself also rarely poses a threat to the player. There are some acid puddles but no lava or bottomless pits to watch out for.

One other glaring issue is the rats. Their hitboxes are small as fuck and they're annoying with the chip damage they do in swarms. They remind me of the bugs in Daikatana and that's no fuckin good.

Another issue would also be the bosses. They require no skill or strategy, and have no tells or weaknesses. Most of the time they'll be turned around, and with no indication whatsoever, they'll do a 180 and fire a bullshit attack at you, so the boss encounters end up being "strafe and jump and shoot" which is essentially what I'm already doing with arena encounters anyway. These bosses dont test my skills whatsoever, and are basically bullet sponges to pad out the game. They don't even have weaknesses.

So basically, yeah, there's a good game at the core here.
-If you want to try a more traditional FPS, buy it. If you've got rose-tinted glasses on when it comes to shooters of the past, buy it. 
-If you play too many shitty current-year shooters and need a humble palette cleanse, buy it. 
-If you're like me and play metric fucktons of old FPSes in their downtime, wait for a sale or pirate and buy it if you like it.

So I guess it'd be a reccomend from me, though with heavy emphasis on a sale, because the game is rather short, which combined with the other flaws doesn't give you as much bang for your buck. You have to realize that a purchase of Dusk at full price is equal to like 5-10 other real old school shooters on steam.

39350856.review:
[b] TL;DR: Get DUSK. It's fucking great. [/b]

When someone tells me that there's a "Retro Throwback Shooter" on Steam, I immediately get skeptical. Usually it ends up being a roguelike with terrible art that's framed as "retro" to mask the fact that there was no effort put in at all.

DUSK finally delivers on the promise. Not perfectly, but closer than most have cared to get.

DUSK leaves the base gameplay mechanics of 90s shooters mostly untouched. It adds a few nice-to-have features like crouch-sliding, unlocked y-axis for flips in the air and in the water, zooming (the Quake 3 kind, not ADS), and some different weapon types. But instead of replacing the core gameplay of something like Quake 1, it adds to it instead. Strafe jumping is kinda here, but it's simplified. Essentially, any time you're moving on a diagonal, you move faster. Jumping diagonally lets you build your speed up to the ridiculous levels you're used to seeing in these kinds of shooters. Anyone who's played these games will be at home after a little adjustment, though don't expect speedrun depth on the level of other shooters.

The graphics are low poly, but work has been done to make it look like the eerie, decayed style of Quake 1 instead of the standard low-effort stuff you see in a number of indie games that don't have a style outside of looking blocky. Even with the intentionally dated graphics, it has this dark, oppressive atmosphere that can go straight to horror at times and make you jump. You're not ready for the Wendigo. I guarantee it. Also, make sure to turn on the limited palette.

The soundtrack is great. Andrew Hulshult does a great job of making a soundtrack that's ambient and unnerving at times, which shifts to metal in tense combat situations or entire levels if it fits. It's great stuff and really makes the game stand out. 

Level design is pretty good. While Episode 1 is a little basic, it's definitely fun and has everything you'd expect in a game like this. Find the keys, kill the dudes, backtrack a little, find secrets, you probably know the drill by now. Episode 2 takes a massive leap. Maps are larger, more creative, stranger, and overall a lot more fun. Without spoiling anything, E2M5 will throw a curveball. I'll just say that it's one of the best levels I've played in a shooter in a while. The rest of the package is great as well.

Lastly, the multiplayer is somewhat rough right now, which is likely my only real complaint. A lot of features you'd expect in an MP game aren't there yet (fleshed out server browser, map variety, other minor stuff that adds up) but this is to be expected given how there's only one dedicated developer who's more focused on making the singleplayer as strong as possible. As a result, the MP isn't fully formed yet, but it's still fun to play. Just don't make it your main focus quite yet. I'll update this review as it gets more fleshed out. And seriously, buff the mortar. It's not even good in SP and useless in MP.

That's about all I have to say about DUSK. It really is that good. The singleplayer is already worth it and I can't wait to see what David Syzmanski has in store for Episode 3. If you have a remote interest in old school shooters, play this now. The fact that I'm giving my approval to a game in Early Access should say something.

39349035.review:
DUSK, is developed by David Szymanski and it's a throwback to the days of Doom and Quake.

Right of the bat you can tell that the developer absolutely loves old school fps games, no hiding behind cover, no reloading, fast paced movement etc.
The game starts off in a room with no explanation and 3 masked chainsaw wielding guys, from that point on the game is almost a non stop shooting fest.


The game is designed to look and play like a 90's FPS, the levels aren't just a bunch of randomized rooms with enemies walking towards you, the levels in the first episode are small but complex.
To complete the levels you are mostly required to find a bunch of keys to open doors or pulling a switch to progress to the next area and solving a puzzle every so often all while shooting down everything that walks in your path.


The game has a good variety of weapons some of which can be dual wielded, you have the pistols, shotguns, super shotgun, assault rifle, hunting rifle, crossbow, mortar and the Riveter.
And honestly no weapon is bad and each weapon feels unique and has it's own place.
Out of all these weapons the hunting rifle is my favourite because of it's high damage and slow fire rate.
There are power-up's as well for example, there is a power which increases your rate of fire for a short period, combine this with the assault rifle and you got yourself a slaughterhouse.


The movement feels like Quake but cranked up, for example after a few jumps you will be able to strafe around the level at maximum speed which feels awesome oh and you're able to do a 180 degree backflip, how cool is that?


The second episode however changes things up a bit, in a good way the levels are still complex but a lot larger and more open.

The second episode also introduces some new enemies and gets rid of some older ones as well as some new power-up's.
Out of all of these enemies  the 'welder' is the most common one and my favourite one as well,
he is a large opponent wielding some sort of machine gun which shoots fireballs and he can be taken care of easily with one shot from the hunting rifle or a couple of blasts from the shotguns.
One of these power-up's allows you to climb quite literally everything, making it easier to reach some secrets or to get a better spot to shoot your enemies.
The other one is where the game changes to Superhot for a short period, meaning that time only moves when you do.
This power up was fun to use but not really all that useful in my opinion.


Now the main problem with these game for me were the boss battles, they are easy to kill and even easier to exploit as well. 
Especially the battle with Big John, he gave me a heart attack which resulted in me spamming the Riveter while he was still in the corridor which took him down in a few seconds pretty much skipping the fight all together.
The only things that I'd like to see different in episode 3 are harder boss battles and maybe nerf the Riveter a bit in terms of fire rate.
Those are really the only issue I have with the game everything other than that is just perfect for me.
The developers pretty much just flipped their middle finger at modern FPS games, no loot boxes, no 60 euro season pass.
This game is everything it promises to be, a kick ass throwback to the good days of Doom, Quake, Blood and Wolfenstein.

So if you are a fan of old school FPS games make sure to pick this game up, it's currently in early access with 2 playable episodes and the Duskworld multiplayer.


Coming to a verdict I feel like this game deserves a 9.5 out of 10.
This is one of the most promising titles of 2018 so far and definitely a must have for FPS fans.
It proves that a team of a few people can do way better than mass budget companies without lootboxes or expansion passes for no more than 20 euros.

39346834.review:
Dusk is a game that tries to recreate the general "feel" of "old-school first person shooters".

It achieves this (surprisingly).

The monotony of the enemies phrases, and sounds they scream at the player, the difference in their appereance and design, the detailed and dreary enviroments that change between levels, the intuitive level design, everything is there.

The fantastic gunplay.

For the most part everything is fine, my only complaints lie with one weapon (the crossbow) which isn't fun to use, nor is it useful in dealing with massive groups of enemies, the one benefit is supposed to be that the arrows go through the enemies, but the bullets of the sniper rifle already do that so...

Then there's the boss battles, I really didn't mind them in the first chapter, simply because I was enjoying the gameplay, and the discovery of the different pathways between levels.

It wasn't until the second chapter when I started to notice problems with it.

All of the bosses are uninspiring, either they are absurd figures that don't fit in any way with the overall theme of the game, or alternatively they are simply "bigger" versions of common enemies.

Then there's the second chapter, the second episode has been a total underwhelming experience for me personally.

The levels are massive this time around but their design hasn't really been improved, similarly to older games, this massive levels for me end up being to annoying to explore, they don't feel like mazes, they feel as massive areas in which you just need to find the right building to then get a key that will open all of the remaining paths of the level.

To me it just feels lazy, both in older games (Doom) as well as in this one.

Maybe it's just me, at this point I've played so much of Doom that those levels, to give an example, just don't bother me anymore, because I know exactly where to go.

Maybe in Dusk it will be the same.

Maybe it should be commendable that that is even something to consider in this game that tries to pay an homage, or alternatively, "take" a lot of elements of old-school games.

Either way, the game is great for the most part, and I really like it, so there.

[b]Playing [i]DUSK[/i] feels like I totally missed a great FPS game that came out in the mid-90s and I'm experiencing it all for the first time in 2018.[/b] It all just feels so good. While there are many high points, I think my favorite part is trying to find all the secrets on each map.

[b]Where to begin, really.[/b] There are metric tons of options and settings, online MP, level completion goals, and more. The gunplay is exactly what it should be, and feels meaty. While nothing here is really that fresh, the dev team simply took the best stuff from classic mid-90s FPS games and recreated that great old-school feel. At the time of writing this, two out of three episodes are available, and while you can technically speedrun through them quickly - there is plenty of content to merit the price tag. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Butter smooth to play, and it's all just so much fun.
+While I see some minor artistic cohesion issues - the theme is unique and works well.
+The sound effects and soundtrack work really well.
+Tons of settings and options.
+Price-point is good.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-While the devs are great in interacting with the community - the community itself is toxic. They cannot take criticism at all. I watched [strike]two[/strike] three negative reviews get run right off Steam (were these valid reviews? I'm not judging that, they paid their money and left their 2cents). Deleted. From the absolutely cruel and abusive comments those reviews recieved, I will assume that was the driving force.
-During my first few playthroughs, there were too many moments where I got confused on where to go in a level, and it was just an awkward break in the action. I thought I was alone with this, but another friend later said he had they same issue (and he actually refunded).
-If you are looking for a modern FPS with modern bells-and-whistles, I think you probably will be slightly disapointed. Not anything wrong with this per-se, but you should know.

[b]If you liked [i]Duke Nukem[/i], the original [i]Shadow Warrior[/i], [i]Quake[/i] or really any of those classic mid-90s FPS games, you [i]need[/i] to get [i]DUSK[/i].[/b] It's great.

39345364.review:
V poslední době je v módě odkazovat na staré dobré hry. U žánru stříleček tohle není výjimkou, a tak narazíte na hromadu vývojářů, kteří se ohánějí slovy oldschool FPS. Snaží se navodit dojem, že právě jejich hra je skutečným zrcadlem do minulosti a i v této době můžou vycházet tituly evokující zlatou éru legendárních titulů jako byl Doom, Blood, Quake, Unreal apod.

Dost dlouho jsem se těšil na hru Strafe, což měl být právě zážitek pro oldschool hráče. Nakonec to nedopadlo zrovna nejlépe a většina lidí byla zklamaná. V té době jsem narazil na Dusk. Dostal jsem se k tomuto titulu jako slepý k houslím a jsem za tu hromadu náhod opravdu rád. Tvůrce hry Dusk si bere za inspiraci tituly jako jsou Blood, Redneck Rampage a Quake, kdy se pokusil navodit podobnou hratelnost. A povedlo se to.

[h1]Zpátky do devadesátých let[/h1]
 Nač chodit kolem horké kaše, když můžu s klidným svědomím už teď odhalit, že vás tahle hra úspěšně vrátí zhruba o dvě desetiletí zpátky do minulosti. FPS hry tehdy neměly žádné RPG prvky, žádný stealth, vše záleželo na vašich reflexech a sžití se s hrou. Byly to jednodušší, ale taktéž i zábavnější časy. První, co mě u Dusk šokovalo, byla rychlost pohybu vaší postavy. Po vzoru klasických FPS jste super rychlí, na což si musíte chvíli zvyknout, ale pak se od toho už těžko odtrhnete a budete si stěžovat, že v ostatních hrách jste extrémně pomalí. Právě pohyb postavy je to, co vás většinou drží naživu. Není problém díky perfektnímu ovládání a odezvě skákat mezi nepřáteli, vyhýbat se útokům a mezitím postupně zmenšovat jejich počet.

Dusk je dle standardu minulého tisíciletí rozděleno na tři epizody, kdy každá čítá 10 levelů, plus jeden tajný. Aktuálně jsou k dispozici pouze první dvě epizody. Zatímco první je taková ochutnávka, která je lehčí a nabízí standardní hratelnost, u druhé už značně přituhuje a jsme svědky několika zajímavých prvků v hratelnosti. Dojde tak i na šplhání po stěnách pomocí háků, zpomalení času nebo se vám dostane do rukou předmět, jehož vhozením do davu nepřátel zajistíte jejich agresi vůči sobě samým. A to se vyplatí.

Každá z epizod, respektive i levelů, má své vlastní téma (=různé prostředí, nepřátele), navazují na sebe logicky a tvoří tak jakýsi příběh. Samozřejmě nečekejte žádné epické dobrodružství plné cutscén. Nečekejte ani filozofický příběh o bytí či nebytí. Vaše postava se prostě ocitla v městě, kde se proti němu spiknul jeden kult. A vy bojujete o život, dostáváte se dál a dál a zjišťujete, že je tu něco temného. Příběh skutečně není silnou stránkou hry, i když je pravdou, že v druhé epizodě začíná nabývat zajímavých rozměrů a mohl by být v té třetí i zpracován více do hloubky. Na prvním místě je však samozřejmě hratelnost.

[h1]Krev, krev a krev[/h1]
A hratelnost je opravdu parádní a výjimečná. Skutečně jsem se díky tomu vrátil zpátky do devadesátých let, kdy záleželo jen čistě na vašich schopnostech. Do rukou se vám dostane vcelku standardní výbava čítající jak zbraně na blízko, tak i na dálku. Některé zbraně můžete mít v každé ruce, takže se tím znásobí vaše palebná síla. Kromě srpů, s nimiž lze odrážet střely, tu je i pistole, brokovnice, dvouhlavňovka, samopal, odstřelovačka, kuš, dva typy granátometu nebo meč. Každá zbraň je vhodná na jinou situaci a proti jinému nepříteli. Není to tedy jen o tupém střílení, ale musíte také používat mozek.

Paleta nepřátel je celkem pestrá, od vesnických balíků s motorovkou, přes členy klanu střílející "firebally" až po ty nadpřirozenější. Je tu i několik zvířat, jako třeba krysy nebo zmutovaný dobytek. Taktéž očekávejte sem tam nějakého bosse. U nich bohužel zatím stačí použít taktiku kroužení okolo nich a střílení ze všeho možného. Jelikož se Dusk snaží evokovat klasiku, očekávejte po každém dokončení levelu zobrazení statistik. Jsou tu také tajná místa, která vám mnohdy dají obrovskou výhodu proti nepřátelům a dost ulehčí hru. Což se hodí, protože už střední obtížnost je vcelku těžká a pořádně prověří rychlost vašich prstů a vaše reflexy.

[h1]Ošklivá grafika[/h1]
Hra je dost brutální, z nepřátel stříká krev, létají všude možně jejich končetiny a některé prvky prostředí jdou zničit. K tomu všemu tu hraje naprosto parádní metalový soundtrack od Andrewa Hulshulta (je zodpovědný za OST k Brutal Doomovi nebo Rise of the Triad 2013). Největší problémy mají lidé s grafickou stránkou hry. A uznávám, že mě to taky zpočátku odrazovalo. Posledních několik let se neschopní tvůrci her schovávají za fakt, že jejich hra je kostičkovaná, protože to je stylizace. Mnohdy je vám ale z toho na blití, grafika je nevkusná nebo jde jen čistě o lenost či neschopnost vývojářů. To naštěstí není případ hry Dusk. Nejde tu o grafiku, ale i přesto má určitou stylizaci, která podporuje temnější atmosféru (zvlášť u druhé epizody se dočkáte hromady okamžiků, kdy budete zírat s otevřenými ústy na tu nádheru). Z obrázků nebo i videí se to těžko pozná, ale jakmile sami vklouznete do bot DuskDudea, po chvíli masakrování nepřátel vám ani nepřijde, že by vizuální stránka nějak zaostávala za zbytkem tohohle klenotu.

K tomu se váže i optimalizace, která je parádní a hru spustíte i na slabších strojích. Navíc jsem nenarazil na žádný bug, což je rozhodně velké plus. Hra je plně odladěná a stabilní. Kromě kampaně tu je již také multiplayer, nekonečný mód, kde čelíte na dvou mapách vlnám nepřátel a po třetí epizodě vyjde i možnost hrát tuhle hru v coopu.

Ve hře jsem strávil nějakých osm hodin, což je dle mě v pohodě vzhledem k ceně a zážitku, jaký mi poskytla. Za těch 17 euro není o čem přemýšlet. Tohle je skutečná pocta všem starým FPS hrám a pokud vás od koupě zdržuje pouze grafika, zbytečně se ochudíte o jednu z nejlepších stříleček za poslední roky.

[h1]Plusy[/h1]
+ návrat do devadesátých let
+ parádní hratelnost s hromadou akce
+ atmosféra (u druhé epizody hororová)
+ design levelů a variabilita prostředí
+ zajímavé zbraně
+ brutalita
+ každá epizoda má vlastní druhy nepřátel
+ délka kampaně
+ nekonečný mód, multiplayer a v budoucnosti i coop
+ úžasný metalový soundtrack
+ perfektní ovládání
+ i když grafika není nejhezčí, ona stylizace má něco do sebe
+ optimalizace
+ nízká cena

[h1]Mínusy[/h1]
- první epizoda je vcelku lehká
- někomu může vadit grafika
- hra je zatím v předběžném přístupu

[h1]Konečný verdikt[/h1]
[b]Mé hodnocení: 10/10[/b]

Pokud jste milovali hry z devadesátých let a nebaví vás je hrát stále dokolečka, Dusk je parádní náhradou. Chyby se na ní hledají jen stěží, cena je příjemně nízká a nevidím jediný důvod, proč si tenhle klenot nepořídit už teď.

39342780.review:
I've taken a bit of a gouge at the surface of the game I'm up to E1M8 so I think it's enough to understand the gameplay. The premise is simple, it's what you wanted STRAFE to be. It does feel like DOOM, maybe not as good as DOOM 2016 but, it does feel like arena shooters of old. Somewhat maze like levels, less mazy than DOOM 1 and 2, a variety of weapons at your disposal too.

One thing that's severely lacking is good death animations, I wanna see people get shredded and destroyed but the only 2 death animations are A: fall over and die, or B: turn into a bloody pulp. I love a good death animation, especially in my arena shooters. This, simply doesn't have them. When you hit someone with a sniper I expect their head to come off, or at least something, they just look like they're a kid getting hit with a nerf dart and then going "ah" before falling over.

The only performance problem with this game is poor optimisation, on my GTX1080 and 6700K with none of the base graphics settings changed it often has FPS drops, skipped frames and often can't handle more than 8 projectile enemies at one time. It doesn't seem that graphically demanding at all... So what's the deal?

Guess it's just what happens when you get early access games, no biggie. The movement feels very good, very responsive, strafe jumping is pretty easy but at least it's there and makes you move around the map very quickly.

Gunplay is spot on, would like a bit more responsiveness from enemies as some are basically bullet sponges, they don't flinch or anything when shot, you just get a little squirt of blood from them, which isn't very exciting.

Boss battles are a nice addition, they don't have much strategy, or multiple stages or anything, but at least they're there.

I recommend raising the difficulty, there wasn't one time on the normal difficulty where I actually felt somewhat threatened by my enemies, the lowest my health has gotten on normal has been 35hp, it makes the activity feel like a leisure, rather than a challenge. 

I do recommend this game, probably not for $20 maybe $15 for your moneys worth so far. There's still a third chapter in the works, It's not as good or interesting as DOOM 2016, but it's definitely better than your other alternatives, like brutal doom, old quakes and things.

If you like arena shooters, go for it. But bring the difficulty up. Also keep in mind things can change, early access after all.

Also an added mention, they're gonna add mod support with the workshop and an SDK in future, so that's really cool. Maybe make some horror maps, parkour, campaigns and things. Sounds good, hopefully it gets enough players to be supported for a long enough time,.

39328545.review:
Ever since GGGmanlives' review of the games' pre-pre-pre alpha, I've waited over a year to get my mits on this thing, grabbed it immediately when they announced it for pre order to play the first episode multiple times (around 30-40 hours specifically), played it some more when the 2nd episode was release to pre order backers and here we are. Dusk is now in early access with Duskworld release to the public.

The game plays like an old 90s shooter if put in a source port. In english term it's classic FPS controls with a modern spin on it instead of enforcing the old MSDOS style of controls (also what's funny is that you can make the game look like it's running in DOS). I guess that can be customized for those who like it that was. The controls are responsive, shooting enemies is satisfying as hell, the bosses while simple are a damn fun challenge (especially Big John). The story as simple as it is, paying homage to the likes of the original Doom, and it works. plus who wants to deal with annoyingly forced scripted events, Quick-time events, and a garbage narrative ala the crappy COD clones of the early 2010s. 

Episode 1 is fun, with it's awesome Redneck Rampage and Blood inspiration to it, musical score and kickass level design and boss fights. I think I'll be regarding episode one of DUSK as my equivalent to the shareware version of Doom that a lot of people had who'd play the living daylights out of Knee Deep In The Dead, because playing the first episode of Dusk feels the same way to me. Episode 2 is a major change from episode 1 in a good way with it's industrial themed, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. and Half Life 1 inspired scenario until the end. Also dissimilar to episode one, for me at least, episode 2 felt more challenging to me, I got my ass wooped more than normal than I did in episode one and NO I don't mean this as a negative, I like it, I'm being challenged by the game. Either that or I'm a masochistic boob who likes pain. Either one will do.

Duskworld as fun too, a little rickity with some stupid spawns that get you spawn killed but still fun.

The soundtrack is... MMM... SO GOOD. Andrew Hulshult is a damn good as what he does best: making some heart pumping tunes.

Mozel Tov to David Szymanski, and the guys at new blood for this amazing experience of a video game. I look forward to future Duskworld updates and the soon to come nameless city (episode 3). Dusk to me will go down as the Doom of my generation (coming out of someone who wasn't alive when the original doom came out) as a guy who followed it in it's early annoucements, loved seeing the previews and falling in love with the preview build that I got to play after pre ordering the game. In a similar but different process that classic doom fans went through 25 years ago. And as much as I loved Doom 4 (and people might hate me for this), Dusk feels more like a more dedicated and more accurate love letter to what makes a classic 90s style FPS fun.

DUSK is a raw injection of pure testosterone into a dying genre. Of all the "this is just like DOOM and QUAKE" clones in existence, Dusk is the only one so far that gets it right. Everything from atmosphere to gunplay is absolutely superb- the game just nails that horror-action-comedy hybrid that made the masterpieces crafted by Id absolutely iconic. One minute you'll be creeping along a poorly-lit nightmarescape, the next you'll be blowing men apart with your godlike boomstick, and the next you'll be chuckling on your character's dry sense of humor.  The flow of combat is perfect, and everything just feels right.

Even in Early Access, DUSK is excellent in make, and a welcome successor to the gun-and-blood built throne currently vacated by DOOM and QUAKE.

39323466.review:
Pillado de salida en el Early, y actualmente dispone 2 de 3 episodios.

Lo tengo en deseados desde el primer minuto que me enteré de su existencia en desarrollo. He crecido todos los 90 volándole el trasero a todo lo que se meneaba en pantalla ya fueran shooters de motores ID Tech, Quake Engine  o Build. Y sabía que su estilo de juego y visual iba a casar con mis intereses al instante.

He completado el primer capítulo y estoy a casi nada de completar el 2º, y, realmente, no me había equivocado.

El juego tiene todos los ingredientes de todos los shooters en los que se basa. Gráficos de Quake, mecánicas rápidas, feroces, sin recarga, sin salud autorregenerativa, sin límite de armas y, especialmente, sin contemplaciones ni refinamientos. Todo se reduce a tu avatar ingame destrozando vilmente todo lo que se le cruza en su camino, sin argumentos que distraigan del puro y duro gameplay noventero y con muchas dosis de metal y ambient sintetizador en los tramos más sosegados.

El resultado hará las mil maravillas de todos los amantes del shooter retro de los 90 como yo. Aunque sólo hay una pega que el juego ignora por completo de esos juegos. El protagonista no tiene un rostro visible ni frases lapidarias. No hay su rostro en el HUD para saber a quién llevamos aunque no diga nada como solía obrar Id Software, ni hay los one - liners cabrones o cachondos de los juegos Build, y es una pena. Pero este desliz no empaña el resultado, si buscas la ferocidad y la falta de complicaciones innecesarias de los 90 mientras el entorno gráfico luce casi calcado al del primer Quake, ni lo dudes. Agénciatelo cuanto antes y disfruta.

El juego ha sido desarrollado por un solo miembro, y el resultado es MUY notable. Siempre es un gran riesgo poner toda la carne en el asador a la hora de lanzar un indie, y como amante que soy del material que se me ha otorgado con este título, doy mi completo apoyo para que llegue a más gente y coseche el éxito que se merece.

100% recomendado para los que busquen estas emociones que yo buscaba en títulos como el que nos ocupa.

39321226.review:
TL;DR Is it worth the asking price? Not yet. Maybe once the third episode has been released, but until then it's over too quickly.

Dusk certainly feels like an authentic 90's shooter. The nostalgia isn't enough to carry the game alone, but fortunately the main package is entertaining enough that it doesn't have to.
The levels are, for the most part, well designed. There were a few difficulty spikes here and there but not enough to become frustrating. I was a little disappointed with the lack of urban environments though. Once you reach the town of Dusk the first chapter ends rather abruptly and the second chapter takes place in more science fictiony type environments. This is a bit of a shame because the Lovecraftian story lends itself well to a Silent Hill crossed with Stephen King's The Mist type of plot and it could have really benefitted from a modern real world setting.

The weapons are mainly functional, satisfying enough but nothing to write home about. I did like the railgun style crossbow that shoots through both enemies and walls and the leaver action shotguns were a blast to use. The double barrel shotgun and hunting rifle were a little bit on the dull side in comparison, and the "riviter" (rocket launcher) felt a tad overpowered.

Powerups are fun, although one in particular I suspect will be an aquired taste. The "Superhot" slow motion powerup is not particularly useful and can get in the way. You have to stand still for it to work which is entirely antithetical to how the game had played up until that point, and you don't fire any faster than the enemy when you're using it. It does give you time to line up shots, but in the cramped environments in which it tends to appear that's not particularly useful.

Multiplayer is, at this time, extremely early access so I won't comment much on that. The deathmatch mode on offer feels rather derivative and doesn't really add anything new. The one server I could get a game on (the others kept bugging out on me) was running a single map back to back, so after 15 or so minuets I was pretty much done.

Endless Mode (survival) feels like an after thought. Currently there are two maps available, with a third on the way. Of the two playable I felt one (the factory) was a little dull and too cramped to be enjoyable.
The core mechanic is pretty simple. Enemies spawn in, kill enemies for points, don't die. If the maps were more dynamic and engaging this could have been more interesting, but as it stands it's at best a brief distraction.

For me the main draw for Dusk is the single player campaign. At the moment two of three chapters are playable, and they're pretty good. The second is lightly weaker than the first and feels a bit on the generic side, mainly taking place in dingy, brown and gray industrial and military complexes. I loved the Lovecraftian bits, but they were too few and far between.

I'm in two minds. I want to recommend this game, but I cant. The campaign is great but not currently long enough to be satisfying. If the third episode lives up to the quality of the previous two I'll have no problem recommending Dusk, but until then it's probably best to hold off until full release.

What can I say?  The New Blood's DUSK should be considered a master class in how to do a retro inspired FPS.  The title seems to take its inspiration from games such as Quake, Doom, Blood, and even Redneck Rampage.  Generally FPS of that era.  It stays true to all of the things that made those games great.  The speed of movement, hectic gunfights, great level design, a very badass metal soundtrack ... it ticks all the right boxes for me.

At the time of writing this the game is in early access and currently comes with Episodes 1 & 2 as well as Duskworld the multiplayer component of the game.  Episode 3 will be coming at a later date ... and if the way it ratchets up from Episode 1 to 2 is any indication of what to expect in Episode 3 then things are gonna be NUTS!

I've recently been playing some of the Duskworld multiplayer and while it also is still a work in progress it is quite fun.  It has the trappings of old school arena shoots.  Health armor and weapon pickups.  It has the same movement as in singleplayer so you can HUP up to quite impressive speeds. The result is yourself and your opponents whipping around the map at blinding speeds flipping twitch shots left and right trying to land the killshot. It is quite hard due to the speed but also quite fun. Each kill is very rewarding feeling. The super shotgun is a beast.

If you like retro-fps this game is made for you.

[h1]これこそ、求めていたオールドスクールFPS	[/h1]
近年、古いFPSタイトルのリメイクタイトルやリマスタータイトルは出ていますが(例:Doom 2016やバイオレンスキラー リマスター)
Duskは、過去作のリメイク等ではなく、純粋なオリジナルタイトルで、初代Quake等の90年代後半のFPSタイトルをイメージして作られています。

39313593.review:
Note: Actual time in game is much longer than shown above, as I played the pore-ordered version for some time and that wasn't added to this version.

Do you like any of the following games-
Quake
Blood
Redneck Rampage
Half Life

Well, then you'll love Dusk. It is an old school first person shooter that, unlike many other shooter that claim to be old school actually is. It's not just the graphics, though- gameplay in every way reflects its origins and influences, with fast movement, no reloading, health pickups,and non linear level design. Control is fluid and intuitive and the art and level design is wonderful. Sound design (aside from the 'take damage' sound, not a fan) especially the wonderful music is fantastic and creates a great feeling.

As I write this review the first two episodes are available, and it's clear that the devs are lerning as they go along. The first episode was heaps of fun, and the second showed definite signs of them getting more confident with how they design their levels as things got much more interesting.

Dusk also has the potential to have a long life- the single player campaign gives you a lot of opportunity to explore, plus there's duskworld for those of you who enjoy deathmatch, endless mode which features you fighting off wave after wave of enemy (much more fun than it seems), and- very importantly- the full game will have mod support which will potentially give the game a huge amount of new content to play with (as it will use Quake 2 format maps).

So a definite recommend. It's $20 (and apparently always will be $20) and is well worth that small amount of money. I mean come on, that's a pretty cheap game right there, considering how wonderful it is.

39312877.review:
DUSK is a really fast paced and entertaining shooter with a wonderful gunplay and retro graphics.
And while I must admit that i haven´t played any old shooters before DUSK I tried to play as much of them after I finished Episode 1.
So I will just list what I like and dislike about this game so far.(Please Notice I reviewing only the first two Episodes of the game)

So to start of with the good DUSK has a real fast and precise movement that really makes it fun to rush in the enemies and dodge their attacks with sliding away. You dont really want to stay far away and be safe like in many modern shooters but to go in close and finish them off with the Supershotgun.

Speaking of the weapons: you can zoom with every weapon except the granade launcher which uses the right mousebutton to let the granades explode.
The weapon models are well made and sound very good. You really have the feeling you are shooting a gun and not some toy.
With 10 weapons you have a real wide variety of guns to use on the different enemies.
They range from shotguns to powerful hunting rifles and the devastating riveter.

A wide arsenal of guns just makes sense if you have different types of enemies you can shoot with and DUSK provides them.
You start off against the weak melee enemies with chainsaws and at the end of episode 2 you face some really strong rocket shooting robots. They all look good and work well even if especially the moose like creatures often run against walls if they cannot find the direct way to the player.
The only enemy that really doesnt make fun is the stationary turret. It´s just standing there and shooting bullets which is pretty lame and in my opinion unecessary.

Im not sure how should I rate the levels because there are some great ones like the first in episode 2 or ghost town in episode 1 but then there are some levels that i guess are supposed to be scary when your flashlight is broken but they just slow you down and leave the best parts of DUSK out. It´s just annoying to crouch down narrow ways to get a key.
So i hope the levels get more open stop trying to be scary in episode 3.

To be honest the game is really short and you might need just around 90 minutes for your first playthrough of one episode or even less if you know the levels. But somehow i managed to spend over 35hours in the first two episodes in the preorder version. That replayability is where DUSK shines you can just jump over the head of a cultist again and again shot dodge and it still feels good. That is also why i have such a huge problem with the slow "scrary levels" even if it scares you once if you replay the level to get sectrets or just for fun its pretty boring because you know where enemies are and where you have to go.

Just to mention it the multiplayer is fine but i do not like to play these games online in general so I cant say anything about.
The Endless mode is perfect for 20mins of fun in between because you have a small map with many waves of enemies and no boring sequences just pure action.

So all in all I really like DUSK so far even if the second episode disappointed me a bit and i would really recommend it if you like fast paced shooters where its the only goal to reach the end of the level no matter how you do it.

39307108.review:
*Note*: I played this game a lot before it hit early access, easily 10hrs+, right now I am taking a bit of a break to wait for the next episode.

DUSK is a new and actual Quake-like FPS with just a bit of Doom, Hexen, Heretic, Duke Nukem, Serious Sam and the likes mixed in, but made to run on modern systems. 
You run incredibly fast, strafe-jump, bounce around wielding an arsenal of guns and shoot swamp-cultists, soldiers, and other monstrosities.

What else is there to tell?

- metal soundtrack in fights (with really nice ambient music) by Andrew Hulshult kicks serious butt
- movement is incredibly fast, smooth and satisfying
- every gun feels powerful thanks to extremely high quality and, most importantly, punchy sounds
- levels are maze-like and have a lot of verticality and depth (visually)
- enemy variety is there, you can distinguish them and they all have some unique behavior
- power ups do exist, only 2 to my knowledge, but it's enough to satisfy your needs
- you can dual-wield shotguns and pistols

Literally the only thing I can complain about, seeing this as a proper old-school FPS, is that the enemies, while varied, do not have very distinctive sounds. Remember the Imp, Pinky, Cacodemon sounds from Doom, still? How you could precisely figure out exactly what demon lurked around the next corner?
Well, DUSK has them too for its enemies, but they're just not as memorable as the classics of yore. At least not all of them.

But, really, if you've been looking for an actual old-school FPS like the best of the 90's were, look no further, this is it.

This is the kind of game I've been waiting for. Was excited for Strafe as that was also a throwback to 90s FPS, but in a way, Strafe didn't do it right. Dusk? It does it right. Dusk doesn't try to be Doom, Quake, Duke Nukem, Rise of the Triad, Redneck Rampage, or any other classic iconic shooter of the 90s. It's its own beast. 39294489.review:
DUSK achieves greatness in that it wears its influences on its sleeve, but also finds ways to carve its own path in terms of the gamplay, story, and its gritty, grimy visuals.

While it looks like Quake, it plays much faster and doesn't have the somwhat bullet-spongey enemies of Quake. You can achieve something similar to the bunny hopping technique of Quake III to move around the maps at higher speeds. Movement serves as your primary defense in battle, and cover will only do so much.

The level design of episode 1 is more functional, but still gives off an aura that something terrible is going on. Episode 2 kicks this up a notch with some pretty awesome levels that you can't help but stare at for a bit.

All of the weapons are satisfying to use, in particular the Super Shotgun (of course) and its thunderous crack of fire and the clicking of its reload. Pressing "R" will spin the weapons, because DUSK has no time for reloading.

If you appreciate the old school of FPS at all, this is very much worth your time. I would still try it if you weren't around for them, just because of the game's evil atmosphere and fast-paced action.

I can't wait to see what Episode 3 has in store.

39294070.review:
So let me preface this by saying I have an additional 30 hours in game not marked here, I had owned a prior version labeled as a separate application before the game full release. That app is now deleted as this main one now takes its place. Regardless

Developed by David Symanski, with music composed by Andrew hulshult, and published by the tiny new blood interactive, dusk is a game with the express hope of kicking the modern shooter landscape in the gut and hightailing it back to the 90s. Its a game I've been watching over the past 2 years and its finally been bumped into early access, so let's talk about it.

Story:


Starting off with the least essential part of any game dusk follows your average unnamed protagonist through the town of dusk as he attempts to figure out what the heck is going.

There's little in the way of plot as story is told through short paragraphs of text and the visual clutter spattered about the environments, all echoing a greater narrative and it works. Its non intrusive whilst being intriguing in its own right and you constantly get the sense something deeper beyond your comprehension is afoot.

Presentation:
Dusk is a game that attempts to not only harken back to the old gameplay of the 90s fps but also their visual style... And it does the latter quite lackingly. Whilst the game certainly looks like it could've been released in that timeframe the visual stylings are quite lacking. There's little use in comparing the visuals to quake as I feel it does that game a disservice, id software were limited with their tech at the time but it feels like despite that limitation they worked their butts off to make something that looked artistically pleasing, as if though it was more a stylistic choice rather than the limitations of technology. Rather dusk looks like someone with little to no artistic skills trying to do something similar which is basically the case through and through as the dev has claimed to be no artist. Ugly texture work, poorly done modeling, awful animations, they permeate throughout this game.

That's not to say the game is a complete dud in the presentation department. The game has amazing sound design, with crunchy guns, and spooky noises as well as an amazing soundtrack. Not to mention those elements combined with the lighting do no short work in making dusk rather atmospheric and spooky at times.

To add to that the only true time I'd consider a game's presentation to be negative is when there's clutter obscuring your vision with crap like motion blur particle effects dof and other schlock being smeared across the screen preventing you from playing and fortunately dusk has none of this. There's little in the way of visual crap and you can always tell what something is supposed to be, at least when you're supposed to that is.

Gameplay:


But obviously none of what I just said matters if the game isn't enjoyable to play which it is through and through. Dusk is a first person shooter in which you navigate intricately designed levels hunting for keys collecting weapons managing resources solving puzzles and fighting hordes of malicious opponents. 

The movement feels fantastic, with glorious bunny hopping and a flowing sensation that makes it feel wonderful to control. There are a variety of utilitarian weapons all of which you carry at once and none of which you have to reload. Managing your ammo, health, and armor, accordingly, as for dispensation against hordes of interesting and fun enemy types prioritizing kinds and strategizing on the fly. Hunting for secrets allowing you to be better stocked and prepared for the fight ahead.

It's all wonderful and incredibly well designed. With some of the best and most memorable levels in all of gaming.


It's an amazing single player experience more than worth the 20$ admission price.

Multiplayer:


But wait there's also multiplayer! And it's good... Yay. To be honest, I'm not a multiplayer guy, so this largely just comes down to it not being my cup of tea but suffice it to say if you love arena multiplayer this should serve ya fine.

Endless:


The only other inclusion is the endless horde mode which is effectively the singleplayer's combat stripped back into a horde mode arena with levels set in locations from each of the games 3 episodes, and its just as enjoyable as the combat in the main game and great for just jumping in and wrecking ham.

Conclusion:


Dusk, in my opinion, is honestly the best fps game to have ever been released and I'm not exaggerating, with the prior best-being doom which this game more than tops in my opinion despite its lacking graphical prowess. It's undoubtedly 10/10.

Люблю первый Quake. Люблю его больше, чем остальные части серии, даже больше, чем ставшую притчей во языцех Q3 Arena. Возможно, конечно, просто синдром утёнка, как эту любовь к старым играм принято объяснять новым поколением игроков, а возможно дело в дьявольски крутом сочетании той самой, на тот момент революционной, но ныне древней 3D графики, где во время взрывов во все стороны летели полигоны, и лавкрафтовской атмосферы самой игры в целом. Не буду лукавить, я до сих пор жду возвращения именно такого Quake.

И я так счастлив, что хоть кто-то испытывает нечто подобное чувство. В DUSK, конечно, далеко не лавкрафтовская атмосфера, но первый обозначенный мой пункт перенесён более чем. Настроил пикселизацию, поставил Low Spec Mode, ещё парочку настроек включил и отключил, и вуаля - чувство ностальгии меня преследует до сих пор, хотя сыграл я на момент обзора всего-ничего, но всё ещё впереди.

Если рассмотреть игру в отрыве от Quake, то игра достаточно бережно отнеслась к предметам вдохновения её разработчиков - это прекрасный спинномозговой шутер с обилием секретов, ультразвуковой скоростью и крутым сеттингом, который уже явно вдохновлялся Blood, который я в детстве, увы, не застал.

В общем, если вы поклонник олдскульных шутеров, то даже особо не раздумывайте - в игре даже мультиплеер есть. Только не хватает HUD'а с лицом ГГ по центру для полного счастья.

39287203.review:
Like everyone else who got the game before Early Access, I have far more time played than is listed here. I have already beaten both the first and second episodes and put in some decent time to the endless arenas, around 76 or so hours total if I recall correctly.

Dusk looks, feels and plays like an oldschool 90s FPS on steroids. The movement feels tight, the weapons feel and sound like they have a big impact even if they don't necessarily (looking at you, pistols,) and the enemies are familiar yet new in designs and roles. The Leathernecks and Wizards for instance could be considered the two parts of a whole Imp from Doom while the Welders from Episode 2's first level and onwards are more akin to the Enforcer of Quake 1, however some enemies such as the Forkmaiden and Black Phillip use familiar ideas in a way that basically makes them brand new offerings unique to Dusk. The Black Phillip has a quick small spit attack but will always gallop towards you fairly fast in an attempt to ram/bite you to death, for example, but it's one of the weakest if not the weakest enemy in the game and thus always comes in packs of 2 or more.

Both episodes are great in my opinion, but as with anything they are not without flaw. Episode 1 is considered by just about everyone who played it to be way too easy because you are essentially drowned in ammunition and can have every gun in the game by the second level in it even going Intruder mode (sickles-only start) by going into three secrets that aren't even that far from each other nor hard in the least to get into.
Episode 2 has a general consensus of being fantastic and more akin to what you would expect of shooters of the day, as it requires more resource management that's reminiscent of the aforementioned 90s FPSes and far tougher enemies to boot. However, some people may find it to be artificially difficult in a few different ways, namely in that you're given less ammo but you have around the same and in some cases even more enemies to deal with that can end up taking quite the bit of punishment and dishing out even more themselves and with some rather cheap Wendigo placements that will almost always slap you the first time through the episode.

From what I've played of Duskworld, you will surely love it if you were a fan of Quake's multiplayer components, and even moreso if you're absurdly good at them as that skill not only perfectly translates into Dusk but is even amplified when you figure out the dirty technical tricks you can pull off with the features Dusk has that Quake never did.

I wholeheartedly recommend Dusk to anyone who's looking for a brand new 90s style FPS that rings almost perfectly true to the games of that era. I'm looking forward to what they'll do with Episode 3 and I'm glad to have gotten aboard this murder train when I did.

39285878.review:
Эта игра вобрала в себя все лучшее от механик таких легенд FPS, как Blood, Doom, Heretic, Quake, при этом одновременно умудряясь быть и похожей на них, и абсолютно другой. Здесь не нужно сетовать на графику. Здесь не нужно жаловаться на отсутствие сюжета - не нужен он. Здесь не нужно вонять, как зачерствевший кусок советского хозяйственного мыла, что "Это уже не тооо, раньше было лууучше, это тупой закос под шутеры 90-х, это позооор, лучше я поиграю в Quake\Doom\Blood" чем в ЭТО и т.д. Не стоит думать, что качество игры зависит от года ее выхода. Всегда есть куча хороших игр, про которые просто знает чуточку меньше людей, чем про мейнстримные проекты. Dusk - как раз такая игра. Здесь нужно просто сесть, нажать New Game и улететь к чертям собачьим с этой планеты. 

Во многом, скептическое отношение к этой игре обусловлено наличем ОГРОМНОГО количества неудачных попыток создать похожие на 90-е игры (имен называть не будем, те, кто читают обзоры на Dusk и так знают, о чем я). Такие игры делятся на две категории: первая - те, которые пытаются давить на ностальгию игрокам при помощи дешевых приемов (ПИКСЕЛЬНАЯ ГРАФИКА ПРЯМО КАК ТОГДА, МНОГА МЯСА КАК ТОГДА), но взамен имеют самые поганые тенденции, абсолютно неприменимые к шутерам - процедурная генерация уровней (а значит, заведомое отсутсвие грамотного левелдизайна), одинаковые враги с одинаковыми атаками, отсутствие интересных игровых ситуаций и т.д. Вторая категория - игры, которые смело заявляют о своей "олдскульности", имея громкое имя - часто это сиквелы и ремейки популярных в 90-е шутеров - однако и тут нам негде развернуться - мы имеем коридорные пострелушки, большие арены, в которых нас запирают с монстрами и не дают выйти, пока мы не убьем всех, а значит, снова отсутвие интересных ситуаций, свободы исследования карт и прочее и прочее.

Я впервые смог опробовать игру в августе 2017 - задолго до запуска в ранний доступ: уже тогда, когда был доступен только первый эпизод, мне все и стало ясно.

Авторы Dusk с самого начала разработки своего детища явно понимали, что именно стоит считать приоритетом при создании хорошего шутера - а именно механику, грамотную расстановку врагов и предметов на уровнях, и т.д. И пусть левелдизайн здесь чуть проще и незатейлевее (особенно это заметно в 1 эпизоде), чем в классических шутерах, тут это скорее идет в плюс - можно наслаждаться игрой, не заморачиваясь, и проходя уровень так, как хочется вам - можно убить всех, можно пройти карту альтернативным путем, можно забить на врагов и пронестись к выходу, пока враги удивленно таращат на игрока глаза, пытаясь понять, чем упоролся этот идиот, что подпрыгивает до небес на собственных ракетах...

Благодаря такому разнообразию от игры просто не устаешь - ее проходишь заново, запускаешь отдельные уровни, проходишь эпизоды, начиная каждый уровень без оружия (в этом случае игра вообще превращается в прекрасный тактический шутер).

Ну и конечно, куда же без эстетики - выстрел из двустволки превращает мешкоголового реднека с бензопилой в разлетающиеся фонтаном кровавые ошметки, пущенная в толпу врагов ракета распыляет их на кровавый туман, брошенный кусок мыла делает из босса гуляш...

Лучше поиграйте сами.

И да, не роняйте мыло.

39279048.review:
Просьба не обращать внимание на количество часов, ибо я проходил игру в режиме отдельного приложения до раннего доступа.

Dusk... Новость о разработке данного проекта я увидел примерно в конце 2016ого года, после чего взял игру себе на заметку. Затем уже в конце лета я нашел игру в Стиме и начал облизываться на этот проект, а на ноябрьской распродаже не вытерпел и взял за фул прайс. Что же я тогда получил? Тогда был лишь первый эпизод, но его было достаточно чтобы понять основные механики игры и некоторые ее особенности вроде неограниченного поворота по оси Y в воздухе. Первый эпизод хорош, не слишком сложен, как и большинство первых эпизодов в старых шутерах, но опасные враги есть и в нем. Затем в декабре вышел второй эпизод. И его я опишу следующим образом:
Ребята из New Blood е.б.ашат вообще адовые эпизоды. Ну такой вот рецепт, усреднённый, потому что вариаций масса. Берется первый эпизод, и он не улучшается, просто улучшать это не про New Blood. Они берут первый эпизод, добавляют минимальную сюжетную привязку, затем вываливают его в сторону и начинают клепать новые карты второго эпизода. Добавляют в них необычные локации, новых врагов, повышенную сложность, бонусы красные и жёлтые, ХОРРОРА! для вязкости, новых боссов сверху. Все это кодится до дыма и остужается в тестовой. Затем New blood заносят новый эпизод в клиент, щедро сдобрив шутками, и начинают играть. При этом играют с читами, шкрябая мышками по столам. Играют и приговаривают полушепотом Dusk will be cancelled SOON™. При этом у них на лбу аж пот выступает. Любезно мне иногда предлагают, и я соглашаюсь. Надо ли говорить какой кайф потом? Отзывы такие, что деньги от кошельков на игру отклеиваются. 

Примерно такие ощущения от второго эпизода, надеюсь третий не подведет. 

В игре 5 уровней сложности, по традиции 4 просто уровня сложности, и один особенный, на котором абсолютно все враги ваншотят вас. Также есть особая настройка, с которой вы всегда будете начинать уровень без оружия кроме стартовых серпов. 

Набор оружия достаточно классический: стартовые серпы, пистолет/два пистолета, дробовик/два дробовика, двустволка, автомат, охотничье ружье (читай снайперка), арбалет, гранатомёт и ракетомет, по-местному риветер. Также есть некая сигара, ее предназначение довольно туманно, но вроде бы она увеличивает скорость передвижения и служит для спидрана. 

А враги? Враги достаточно разнообразны и опасны. Крысы, культисты, колхозники с бензопилами, учёные, солдаты и прочая разнообразная нечисть, сами увидите, если не играли, не хочу некоторых спойлерить. 

В целом уровни довольно колоритны, наполнены секретами и врагами, присутствуют особые временные бонусы народе скорострельности, так что будет чем развлечься. 

Ну и какой же олдскульный шутер без боссов, в которых вы должны выпустить N-ный процент боезапаса, чтобы убить. Босс батлов на каждый эпизод будет несколько, вот только сами боссы не самые сложные, учитывая что главный герой, по аналогии с Думгаем Duskdude, владеет быстрой распрыжкой с отличным эир контролем в духе CPMA, но всё-таки боссы здесь хорошие, качественные.

И куда уж без музыки, пусть я плохо разбираюсь в жанрах, но здешняя музыка хорошо подходит мрачному и безжалостному окружению, скорее всего это какая-то разновидность рока или металла.

По итогу я советую Даск тем, кто хочет поиграть в старую игру по-новому, и если вас не пугают бритвенно острые полигоны, то вы сможете покрутить десятки настроек, запустить во врага камнем, или лезвием, или... мылом, совершить кувырок через голову с места, ну и получить много положительных эмоций от классической формулы хорошей стрелялки с сюжетом как в порно.

39278983.review:
This game is not just a great throwback to the frantic and cathartic FPSs of the nineties, it's also a great action game of it's own with one third of it being a suspenceful somewhat horror experience and the other two thirds being pure unadulterated action. Episode one is a great introduction in the rural backwaters of Pennsylvania with action packed levels overrun by cultists, episode two is a much more horrific experience with the action, environmental storytelling and fucked-up ness all dialed up to eleven in levels comprised of grimy military facilities and other disturbing locales.

Now the game is very much a fast paced shooter with insane combat pacing and skill based movement that's easy to learn but hard to master. When the game isn't a guns-blazing action experience it has a very good weird and disturbing feel to it with heavily grungy places and scary monsters like cultists, possessed soldiers, demons and inhumane military experiments. Each levels are totally different experiences going from claustrophobic to wide open, all of them have something memorable or special.

Now the soundtrack composed by the great Andrew Hulshult is an exellent mix of head banging combat tunes and great ambient soundtracks that really set the mood for the levels.

Overall I'd say DUSK is equal and sometimes even better than most classic 90's FPSs in everything exepept for legacy. This is without a shadow of a doubt my game of the year 2018 and one of my favorite first person shooter of all time.
