39277740.review:
I still have so much to dig into with this game, but I love the pace and style of the single player. The levels are large and interesting enough to make me want to replay them. There's so much here that I'm excited to replay these levels before I even finish the main quest. Endless mode is a great, really suits this style of game with the HP/armor/ammo management. I woke up this morning excited to play Dusk, and it takes a LOT for a game to do this to me these days. Visual style is great, and somehow these devs have made the first Unity FPS I've ever played that actually makes shooting feel good.

There is multiplayer too, which is really energetic and fast. It feels a bit like a caricature of classic Quake gameplay, for better AND for worse. It's fun and easy to pick up, but lacks a lot of the depth I want in this kind of FPS. I will definitely be playing online but it won't steal me away from Quake - although I don't think it wants to. MP is designed to be fun to pick up above anything else and I respect that.

If you like classic single player Quake/Doom/Duke 3D/etc then buy this. You will get lots from the offline and be able to play some fun online games to boot.

39271398.review:
This game is a must have for anyone who is a fan of classic style shooters.

Not only does this game have strafe jumping mechanics and jump pads to help you zoom around the level, but they also include an item throwing ability that is similar to the gravity gun in Half Life 2, giving the player the ability to chuck explosive barrels and gasoline cans wherever they want, leaving a ton of creative options for how they want to take on hordes of enemies.

However, my favorite edition to the game has to be the wall climbing ability introduced in the beginning of Episode 2. It's so much fun just jumping from building to building, navigating yourself around the level. If there is any sort of Capture the Flag mode for multiplayer I hope this gets put in.

39271359.review: This game is fantanstic - a true spiritual successor to old school FPS like Blood and Quake, which are my all time favorites from the mid 90s. Unlike other games that slavishly follow what was done by its influences, DUSK takes what works from those games and incorporates modern elements to create something new. The visuals, audio, music, level design and game feel are all superb. Some people criticise DUSK for being "looking bad" but to me that's like criticizing Shovel Knight for its pixel art. The developer is going for a particular aesthetic and I think it's really well done in its execution. It just so happens that most developers aren't interested in recreating early 3d art, which is all the more reason DUSK stands out.

39270962.review:
2018's peaked early folks, DUSK's won and it's not even fully released yet.

For realsies though, as someone born in the latter half of the 90's I've only heard myths and legends of the delightfully terrifying chaos of old school FPS; Tales of uncapped framerates, FOV sliders, franetic speed, advanced movement, relentless action and the oppressively daunting feeling that, amist the pop culture references and fragging, an unspeakable evil lurks within the gamecode. DUSK isn't inspired by 90's shooters, it IS a 90's shooter and it delivers upon it's promise in all the right ways.

Please marry me DUSK, we'll prance together through the murky cornfields, flies sweeping past our faces, and when the sun settles beyond the horizon we'll lay upon the corpse-riddled fields and gaze up at the awe-inspiring cosmic horror in the night sky.

39270344.review:
You know Pagan orgies, right ? Well, to be perfectly honest with you, DUSK is like if DooM, Quake, Heretic, HeXen, Redneck Rampage and Blood had a baby altogether. At once. Yes, it sounds weird, but trust me, it's not.

You always hear here and there that "This game is such a throwback to the FPS Genre" or "I've never played such an old-school classic". Well, this time, it's truer than the last ones. For real. I mean, how in 'tarnation could all these references not do something wonderfully awesome when you mix them together ?

The answer is simple : if it weren't done by these guys (NewBlood if I'm correct), it would be a piece of trash. Fortunately for you, they know what they're doing. Not only they love old-school mechanics, not only they understood what "WHERE IS THAT LAST F--- SECRET I'VE BEEN LOOKING FOR THE LAST 20 MINUTES ?" truly mean, not only they seem like they've been bathed in FPS since their birth, but they also seem to have nailed the level design like no one before -or so.

If you're looking for what I'd like to call what Old School Made Goddamn Right... Well, sir or madam, look no further, for your eyes will feast on pixels, for your heart will race on the fast-paced levels Dusk has cooked for you and your ears will truly bleed with joy after the magnificent and powerful soundtrack.

I wish I could do a pun saying that if you play this game, it'll get you from DUSK till Dawn, but I think that would be out of place, don't you think ?

Vous avez déjà entendu parler des orgies païennes ? Pour être tout à fait honnête, DUSK serait l'enfant conçu durant l'une de ces dernières, si DooM, Quake, Heretic, HeXen, Redneck Rampage et Blood étaient de la partie. Je sais, ça parait bizarre, mais faites-moi confiance, ça ne l'est pas du tout.

Vous avez déjà entendu "C'est le meilleur hommage au FPS jamais imaginé" ou "Je n'ai jamais autant pris mon pied sur un jeu si old-school"... Et bien, cette fois, c'est encore plus vrai. Vraiment (oui, j'aime les répétitions). Sincèrement, comment voudriez-vous qu'autant de références mélangées ensembles arrivent à enfanter autre chose que la perfection ?

La réponse est simple : si le jeu n'avait pas été développé par les gars de NewBloods, ç'aurait été clairement oubliable (pour rester poli). Heureusement pour vous, ils savent parfaitement ce qu'ils font. Non seulement ils aiment les mécaniques de jeu old-school, non seulement ils comprennent complètement le "OÙ EST CE P--- DE SECRET QUE JE CHERCHE DEPUIS 20 MINUTES ?", non seulement ils ont l'air d'avoir baigné dans le FPS depuis leur plus tendre enfance, mais ils semblent également avoir parfaitement intégré le level-design comme personne auparavant -ou presque.

Si vous cherchez ce que je me plais à appeler un jeu "Old-School fait avec un sacré talent"... Eh bien, Madame, Monsieur, ne cherchez pas plus loin, car vos yeux se régaleront des pixels, votre cœur battra la chamade au gré des niveaux nerveux et rythmés et vos oreilles saigneront de bonheur à l'écoute de cette OST du feu de Dieu, puissante et bourrine à souhait.

Je ferais bien un jeu de mot vous disant que si vous posez les doigts sur DUSK, vous passerez une Nuit en Enfer, mais que vous en ressortirez transformé, mais je pense que ce serait déplacé, n'est-ce pas ?

En tous cas, en achetant DUSK, vous ne ferez pas qu'apporter aux créateurs de cette œuvre d'art un sourire béat sur leurs visages -et, j'en suis certain, leur amour éternel ainsi que leur vénération inconditionnelle pour avoir supporté leur travail- mais vous vous ferez aussi du bien, parce que ce jeu est juste génial et passer outre serait un crime !

Il se pourrait, accessoirement, qu'après avoir joué à DUSK, vous ne voyiez plus le savon de la même manière... Surtout quand il est parfumé au bacon.

i'm only reviewing the multiplayer since that's the only thing i really play these days.

duskworld a fun, fast paced afps with an emphasis on position and weapon control.  there are major item pickups (super health, diamond) but they're not as important as the ssg, xbow, or mg.  movement feels like ratz instagib combined with doom2 plus stairclipping.  

game works well for both duel and pubdm.  for duel, we generally see fusillade (small open arena), cliffside (large open arena), and temple (large room-based arena) played as the default pool.  each works to a different skillset, so if one wanted to do a bo3 there is room for pickbanning to a map you prefer.  weapon balance leans towards hitscan favored for high and mid ping and xbow favored for low/host ping.  TTK is significantly faster than traditional afps titles, including cpma.  one clean shot from ssg is enough to instagib most stacks.  imagine every weapon had the dps potential of qw lg.

if you're looking for an aim-based afps title, this will probably scratch your itch.  if you want a methodical game, you're probably going to get very frustrated very quickly.  personally, i enjoy this game's take on duel.

39266620.review:
I fondly remember those nights that I stayed up way too late fragging snarling monsters back in the late 90's and early 2000's. I still grin whenever I revisit those old pictures from past LAN parties which showed row after row of beige CRT monitors. Doom, Quake and Half Life were but a few of the must have games at the time. However, as time went on the gaming industry shifted away from its older design principles as the hobby moved into the mainstream. Detailed and challenging level design was left in the dust in favor of linear corridors and "cinematic" events. Dusk is a true labor of love and a return to what many consider to be the golden age of PC gaming.

Dusk doesn't coddle its players. The second the intro screen fades to black after launching the campaign the game immediately throws you into the action. There are no objective markers and there is no minimap. Dusk leaves it up to the player to discover its secrets and to navigate its deadly levels. On all but the easiest of difficulties the games many enemys will hit you hard. Should you parish to a barrage of bullets or have the misfortune of being torn apart by some lovecraftian horror you will quickly find yourself back at the beginning of the level. Unless of course you planned ahead and mashed that quick save button!

There will be those who will scoff at Dusk's graphical presentation. The game looks old but that was the developers goal. Everything from the chunky, pixelated graphics to the raw power chords of the games soundtrack is all by intentional design to capture the essence of 90's shooters. Dusk is a true doorway back to that era of PC gaming. For those of you who never touched a PC game back then or maybe were too young I strongly urge you to give Dusk a shot, The game sounds good, feels good and is a blast to play.

39265338.review:
*Note: Although it says 2.2 hours on here, I actually have a combined total of around 28 hours including the original client before this game went on early access

While it's not without some issues, Dusk is a solid 90's style FPS and is a blast from start to finish. To keep it simple, I'll break it down into all the pros and cons I can think of:

PROS
-Excellent controls, fluent movement, and meaty, satisfying shooting mechanics
-Guns feel powerful and useful; no weapon goes unused (other than the starting melee weapon) and each has certain 
 enemy types that its better or worse against
-Superb level design that continuously improves and gets more creative the further you get into the game
-Becomes a real challenge once the difficulty ramps up
-Multiplayer is fast, fun, skill based, old-school carnage
-Great value with 3 episodes totalling 33 levels, numerous secrets, 3 endless arenas, multiplayer, with coop, mods, and 
 achievements coming later
-Nice variety of environments, with distinctive feel and tone between episodes
-Creepy, sometimes downright horrific atmosphere backed by excellent art and sound design
-Andrew Hoscholt's (spelling?) Soundtrack is top notch with a mix of heavy metal, industrial, and ambient music tracks
-Numerous "wow" moments throughout the levels where you just have to stop and appreciate all sorts of views, set 
 pieces, and other standout moments
-Honestly just never gets old; I've played the game start to finish several times over and I feel like I could continue to do 
 so over and over for quite some time; additionally, there are secrets to hunt for, medals to unlock, and there's Duskmare 
 difficulty and intruder mode to provide some extra challenges and new ways to play
-Despite the incredibly small dev team and the huge undertaking this game has been for them, the game is almost 
 completely bug-free in single and multiplayer; the few bugs I have experienced have been minor - no crashes, freezes, 
 corrupted saves, or anything of the sort to speak of

CONS
-Boss battles tend to be overly simplistic; usually only have one attack pattern and, other than for a couple of bosses in 
 episode 2, there's no real creative use of the environment in these encounters
-Presentation is a little TOO simplistic, even for the time period it's emulating; enemy and weapon models are a bit too 
 low-poly, and animations are overly simple and unmemorable
-Episodes are pretty short; for anyone with experience in 90's twitch-shooter FPSs, each episode will proabably only take 
 2-3 hours each, making the entire game only 6-9 hours long; once you get really good and know the level layouts in 
 your head you can breeze through each level in a minute or two even on the highest difficulty 
-Episode 1 is incredibly easy even on the highest difficulty; it's not really until episode 2 begins that the game becomes a 
  proper challenge
-As of now, the multiplayer community is still tiny, and there's usually only a couple of decent sized games going at any 
 particular time

Overall, the core of the game is fantastic and the cons have done little to dampen the experience. To anyone a fan of old-school, fast paced, twitchy FPS's like Doom, Quake, Blood, etc., I completely recommend this game. To anyone who prefers slower, cerebral, or story-heavy experiences, or who doesn't care for the 90's aesthetic in the graphics, this isn't going to be what you're looking for.

39263773.review:
DUSK is a blended mixture of the chaotic battles of Doom II and the harrowing frights of STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl. It finds its stride in deliberate pacing; carefully crafted moments of sinister dread meeting the loud and cantankerous unloading of a double barrel shotgun. The levels are handcrafted, a delightful departure from recent entries of the retro-shooter sub-genre, and chock full of memorable encounters and atmospheric locales. With secret items and even whole hidden levels, it will keep you coming back as you wish to scrounge every nook with your rustic sickles.

It is perhaps apt that, in the decades following the explosive boom of the First-Person Shooter's arrival to gaming, it would be a small team with ambitious ideals to recapture the spirit of its forebearers. You'll find no tutorials, cutscenes or intrusive narrative here. Everything to be found lies within the cornstalk fields, abandoned factories and unholy temples of DUSK. 

Disclosure: I was a tester of the game during development.

As for DUSKWorld (multiplayer) it is exactly the kind of online FPS experience I have craved for YEARS! It is in every sense of the phrase classic fragging goodness! No classes, no lootboxes, no focus on eSports, just FUN!

Oh and I have to mention the soundtrack by Andrew Hulshult which in my opinion is nearly PERFECT! It perfectly blends ambience during more slow sections (like Quake) with adrenaline pumping metal awesomeness (like DOOM)!

I have had more fun experiences with DUSK than pretty much any other game and I couldn't be happier! The developers have been some of the nicest, funniest, and most transparent game developers I have ever come across and they truly have put their blood, sweat, and tears into DUSK! I congratulate them once again on the early access launch and I can hardly wait for Episode 3 and the mod tools! DUSK has truly been a bright spot in my life and I am forever thankful. 

Buy this game!

39261823.review:
This is a lucky time for a twitch-shooter fan to be alive.

I'll preface this review by saying simply that I'm a long time fan of the genre, and hold QUAKE 1-3, DOOM 1-2, Duke Nukem 3D, Blood, Hexen and Heretic in very high regard. DUSK, what you see before you, carries on their great work in a stylish way.

It'd be understandable for a game to seek fortune by outright emulating these old masterworks, yet DUSK does something quite remarkable in its interaction with the past. There certainly are overt homages to the days gone by: labyrinthine levels, chunky (in sound, feel and appearance!) guns, vicious enemies and often brutal difficulty are all welcome inclusions. However, I find that the true appeal of DUSK is its manipulation of these themes, preserving the great and making the not-so-great of the old days more accessible. DUSKDUDE is able to interact with his environment by blowing open walls, picking up objects, stacking boxes and quaffing beers. It's hilarious, over the top, and down-right magnificent.

The guns, level-design, opponents and warped sense of humour all combine to create a wonderfully brooding atmosphere that's wholly absorbing. You'll find yourself entranced by it's devilish charm, gallons of blood and rhythmic pounding.

All of which is without mentioning the musical work of the legendary Andrew Hulshult. His magnificent score sounds like a combination of Nine Inch Nails, Gary Numan, Killing Joke and so many others, yet retains his trademark grasp of melody and pace. It's the very, very tasty cherry that's on top of a delicious cake. Well done to you, sir.

The multiplayer is also hilariously fun. Prepare your ears for gunfire and the game's signature "HUP!" of bunny hopping. Endless hours of entertainment await.

Stop whatever you're doing and buy this game. Support some of the best and most talented developers around. Experience DUSK.

P.S.S . Обзор будет обновлен , как выйдет 3 эпизод / игра выйдет из Раннего Доступа ( карточки/достижения завезут ) . Я ,  впрочем сомневаюсь , что мое  мнение кардинально изменится . Ведь 2 эпизодом авторы смогли изрядно удивить и порадовать и самое главное - показать , что они могут расти над собой  .

39261139.review:
[i][Disclaimer: My playtime reset when Dusk entered EA, but I have about 30 hours total.][/i]

Dusk came out of nowhere for me. I learned about it from one of [URL=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lA6OOdV4Ve4]LGR's videos[/URL], and went in with the cynical expectation that it'd be another faux-"throwback to '90s shooters" that completely misses the mark. Not only was I completely wrong, but Dusk ended up being one of my favorite games of 2017/2018.

The retro-FPS inspiration that Dusk wears on its sleeve isn't superficial; it can be felt in the gameplay and the level design, which is what immediately sucked me in. Levels are open-ended and immaculately-crafted, each sporting their own memorable set-pieces. The various monsters (which are continually introduced throughout the game) all have their own unique attacks and gameplay gimmicks, which keep Dusk feeling fresh from level to level, episode to episode, Replayability is immense, as Dusk offers unforgiving difficulty settings, melee-start mode, and loads of well-hidden secrets (along with a shiny, meaningless medal for finding all of them).

The weapons, simple as they look, are all very satisfying to use. None of the guns suffer from any sort of "obsolescence" later into the game, and you'll often find yourself switching from shotgun to hunting rifle to machine gun as different obstacles demand different arms.

[i]DuskWorld[/i], the multiplayer component of Dusk, only has deathmatch at the moment. I've played about 5 hours of it, and it gave me some fun flashbacks to HLDM; if you like fast-paced arena FPS gameplay, you'll probably enjoy DuskWorld to some extent, but the single-player package is more than strong enough to warrant a purchase by itself.


I'd wholeheartedly recommend Dusk to anyone who has longed for a new shooter that follows the conventions and design principles of the classics like Doom, Blood, and Quake; it really doesn't get much closer than this.

39260186.review:
[h1] Kill The Intruder [/h1]

Are you looking to get your retro/old school FPS fix that these "Modern" games can't seem to satisfy? Were you disappointed with Quake Champions as I was? Well look no further as DUSK IS FINALLY HERE!! ... Well in Early Access at least! I've been following DUSK since it's announcement, and have played all the alphas and demos, and purchased it when it was first available. This is a true love letter to the old shooters and it shows it with pride! Inspired by Quake, Blood, Heretic, Hexen, Half-Life, Redneck Rampage and all the '90s favorites!

[h1] Story: Be Branded a HERETIC [/h1]
The main game is the 3 Episode campaign (Episode 3 is still in the works, which is why it's EA.) You will embark on a quest to murder everything in your path such as cultists, possessed militants and even darker forces to discover what dark secrets and horrors are hiding in this world. Much like the old shooters, the emphasis isn't full on story, but more on the gameplay and mechanics. The story is told in little interactions here and there, as well as from the world/map you explore in and you try to piece it together yourself. 

You want some Multiplayer? Where it's here as well! DUSKWorld (See what they did there?) where you can jump and flip around levels playing an actual proper Deathmatch with weapon pickups and no Hero Skills/loadouts.

There is also an Endless Survival Mode for if you wanted that total carnage to never stop and just keep on killing.

[h1] Gameplay: Rampage Past The Rednecks [/h1]
The main focus of these games is always the gameplay. There is a reason why so many people love the old FPS games, cause they were FUN! The combat feels meaty and responsive. There is no bullsh*t or cheap deaths. Each weapon feels useful and powerful. Movement is fast and responsive. The game makes you feel like a badass when you launch off a jump pad, do a sick backflip while shooting a rocket, then landing with a slide while pulling out your double barrel shotgun and blasting the enemy in the face! The combat feels straight out of QUAKE, but with their own little twist! What I'm saying is this is the new QUAKE we were wanting Bethesda!

[h1] Audio: Meet Your DOOM [/h1]
Audio is perfect. The world has sounds and the enemies have their own unique sounds, but lets face it, the MAIN focus for me was the soundtrack! Made by no other than Andrew F*cking Hulshult! This soundtrack is metal as f*ck! It's another one of those soundtracks that you will listen to more outside the game cause it's just that god damn amazing! Andrew Hulshult knocked it out of the park again!

[h1] Graphics: QUAKE In Fear [/h1]
DUSK definitely shows off it's retro style. It gives off a strong QUAKE, Blood, Heretic, Hexen, Half-Life, and Redneck Rampage feel depending on the level. Each levels feels new and unique. As it looks like an old shooter, the game isn't graphically demanding and runs super smooth. I don't think this game dipped under 240FPS for me once, and I don't have a super computer! You can tweek the graphics slightly, like making the game look pixelized to make it feel even more older, change the color settings to make it feel like it's from Blood, or Hexen, or even in black and white! You can change your FOV, change the weapon model sizes, and even if you want smooth textures. The options menu isn't a huge choice of settings, but like I said this isn't a graphically demanding game so you probably won't have any issues running the game.

PROS:
- It's everything a retro inspired FPS should be, and more!
- Graphics are great!
- Andrew Hulshult soundtrack is ALWAYS F*CKING AMAZING!
- Great selection of weapons that are fun to use.
- Great selection of maps/levels.
- Lots of secrets to be found.
- Multiplayer is a great fun to play.
- [spoiler] Dope Fish Lives! [/spoiler]

CONS:
- It's EA (still in the works, but not really a con.)
- *There is some extremely toxic fans, and that's just pathetic!
- No Achievements (YET)
- No Steam Trading Cards (YET!)

Summery:
In case you can't tell, I love this game to bits, and plan on sinking some major time into it. If the trailers don't give you a hard on, then you obviously don't like good FPS games.

I'm also waiting for them to announce the big box collector's edition that I will 100% buy to have it sit on my shelf. This is a game that I want to happily display on the shelf next to the other great classics... If I owned them. >_>

So yes, $20, now and forever. Buy it already!

=======================================
EDIT:
So there is a slight edit to this... It's nothing about the game, but more or less the extremely toxic fans that seem to have surfaced recently. The toxic levels of if you say ANYTHING bad or critique the game they come after you like rabid dogs, causing people to delete their comments or review. At least the Devs know this is a problem and have told people to chill the f*ck out!

This game is heavily inspired by classic Quake, Blood's dark humor and Half life2  in term of visuals, mechanics, and atmosphere.
Mostly everything is on point for me and it really scratch an itch I have never been able to do ever since the 90s.

Dusk will make you discover what makes a FPS good by displaying great level design ideas, music and sound effects, environment interaction (lift objects and jump ontop of them to get somewhere higher, press switches, use a flashlight to see, walls climbing mechanic), very well tuned guns mechanics, abilities and power ups. The character movements feels unlike anything you experienced even in Quake. You can actually perform flips, power slides and move so freaking fast!!

The single player campaign episodes are very well crafted and horror inspired as you find scientists experiments everywhere and insane cult members around them. The multiplayer is a killfest as you would expect but It is still too recent for me to mention anything beyond that for now.

The only 'pale' side I feel for this game is the very low amount of polygons 3D design for some guns, areas and creatures which make them looks quite simple. I have quickly closed my eyes on that because this is such a great game anyway. 

9/10

39251821.review:
IT IS FINALLY HERE. Well, almost. But it's PRETTY DAMN CLOSE.

I have been following this game since 2016 at quakecon, where I saw this being showcased and met the 3 or so people that worked on this game. I saw this game and was blown away (at that time, they only had the survival mode and let people play) but boy, was it fun. Despite Quakecon being filled with tons of other fun stuff to do, I constantly saw myself going back to the DUSK booth, probably anoyed the crap out of them too. I have been watching this game like a hawk waiting for its release. I played it again at the previous quakecon 2017 and was even more amazed at how much more solid the game became,

My favorite game of all time is a 3 way tie between Quake I, Blood, and Doom(original). All 3 of those games were clear influences on this one, and it isn't afraid to show it one bit. 
After 2 and a half years of me waiting, I FINALLY can play this game whenever I want. 

If you are a 90s fps gamer/fan, I definitely won't be the first to say that this is your wet dream come true. This game feels like a bunch of the big ones: in specific the 3 that I named, as well as other influences like Heretic and Redneck Rampage, mashed together into one. It's even FASTER than Quake, something I never thought would be possible.  

The singleplayer is broken down into 3 episodes, with a total of 33 levels. On top of that, there is Duskworld (like Quakeworld) for hours of multiplayer fun, and there's even 3 diffrent "endless mode" levels. So for 20 bucks, this is a massive bang for your buck. Hours and hours of content for the price of 2 meals. Definitely worth it.
This also has soundtrack was in fact done by Andrew Hulshult. If his music is in it, that's already a sign it's gonna kick a$$.
The overall gameplay is very 90s at the core; kill anything that moves, find cards/secrets, and find the level exit and move on. But the level design is great, as every level feels diffrent to keep the game fresh, and it feels like true progression instead of random levels; one of the major issues I felt 90s games had. I have only 2 VERY minor complaints. Though I love the level design, there are some points that are a tad confusing and can be irritating for people that aren't used to oldschool level design. Even for me those points were a bit confusing. (very minor complaint). My only other one shouldn't even be worth mentioning because Andrew is fixing it, but it's the timing of the switching between the ambient and metal music is off at some parts. But they're both amazing and very fitting for the level and game. They're good enough to listen to as actual songs on their own, so you might want to do your ears a favor and buy the soundtrack. Regardless on what you think of the game, you will like the music if you're into metal and dark ambient music.

If you like easy, boring realistic shooters that hold your hand 24/7, then you'd probably want to look elsewhere. But for those that want a guininely fun, challenging, and aesthetically pleasing game, then look no further.
I'll eventually make a video review on this in full depth and analysis, but for now quit reading this and just grab it because it is one of the best games you will play all year- possibly all decade.

39251753.review:
Dusk is genuinely amazing, an fps modeled after the grand-daddies of the fps genre with an interesting story and atmosphere, and a lot of unique ideas.
First things first, though I rarely use it the unlocked axis is a clever idea I'm surprised I've never really seen before.
The episodes released at the moment are well-crafted and really do feel like something you'd have seen from quake or doom. With a bounty of settings for players of all shapes sizes and hardware specs, the game is almost certain to run on your system. New Blood has more than proven themselves to be one of the next great developers of our time with dusk alone and after getting to play a couple of their other titles I'm happy to say I'm eager to see more.
Duskworld, as well, is a fast paced, frantic multiplayer mode that even in such early stages is a delight to play, and is a nice way to pass the time. Dusk is definitely worth your purchase, and if not it's worth keeping an eye on. I have a feeling this is one we're going to remember.

39251613.review:
tl;dr if you like old shooters like Quake, Doom and Hexen, you'll enjoy this game too!

You've probably read the same thing in lots of other reviews of this game, but DUSK manages to capture the feel of oldschool FPS games like Quake while also feeling fresh and interesting at the same time.
What makes it stand out, in my opinion, is that the game manages to fuse fast-paced action and a creepy horror-atmosphere together. I have played Episodes 1 and 2 before the game launched into Early Access. Episode 1 is pretty much what you would expect from a game like this, there are not too many moments which you haven't seen in other games as well but DUSK delivers them in a really competent way. Episode 2, however, experiments much more with its level design and I think the game really found its way here. Saying anything more would be a spoiler so I'll just say that the game develops its own style in Episode 2 and that style works really well.

At the time of writing this, my only worries are that DUSK will remain a relatively short game. There are 3 Episodes planned and I have played 2 of them already. Every Episode seems to have about 10 levels (I think), which makes for a good 30 levels to play through, which is fair, but I would love to see even more content for this game. That being said, the developers are apparently planning on releasing a SDK and Workshop support, I think the community around this game might be the key to more levels in the future. 

Furthermore, the game also features an endless wave-based horde mode which is good fun if you need a quick session of shooting stuff. Also, the multiplayer is fun as well and it is refreshing to play a multiplayer-mode with weapon pick ups and only your KDR to keep you occupied in comparison to all the progression-system, microtransaction and loadout-laden multiplayer titles out there. 

Solid recommendation: 9.5/10 at the time of writing (Day 1 of Early Access release)

39251296.review: Played a ton of this game before it was in early access. This game has probably the best controls I have ever seen in an fps game, everything you do is super responsive and smooth. The level design in the episodes released so far is pretty amazing, each level has perfect enemy and item placement, and the gameplay is super fast paced, like quake and other 90's shooters. Each weapon is unique, and has it's own strengths and weaknesses depending on the situation. A feature I really appreciate is the optional "intruder" mode, which makes you start each level with your default melee weapon, which is a really nice challenge for when you've already beaten a level as you must relearn the level's layout and prioritize finding a good weapon and ammo rather than just rushing for the keys and next objective.  Not only is the action amazing, but this game has a really effective horror atmosphere, with episode 2 introducing one of the most frightening enemy types I have ever seen in a video game. I definitely recommend playing this game with headphones, as it makes for a very immersive fps experience, especially in the horror department. Overall this game gets a 10/10 from me so far and I can't wait for episode 3.

39251048.review:
Awesome game so far. There's been a very niche market where developers try to cash-in on the joy of classic shooters, but typically fail due to injecting a weird modern aspect to it, be it rogue-lite mechanics, or trashy old-but-not-old "retro" pixelated graphics. Dusk doesn't do that. Dusk is exactly what it says it is, and pursues to be exactly what it wants to be: a love letter to id software's Quake.

Great features, great options, great aesthetic, great gameplay. The level design, at least in Episode One, I dare say is a little too simplistic and flat (still NOT boring!), but Episode Two has proven to be a very strong step in the right direction. One unique aspect to Dusk's level design though is that the developers aren't afraid to shape tension. Not every corridor and open space is designed with the intention to be the next big side-strafing fight, it makes great use of space to build atmosphere to really throw you into the fact that this game wants to - at times - make sure you know it's horrific. It's one of my favourite things about it.

Expect fun weapons, fun fights, and downright terrifying/tense moments. Seriously. Prepare to have your butt clench. A lot.

Worth every dollar.

39250589.review:
A faithful recreation of the mechanics popularized in Quake, DUSK presents an entertaining foray into a world of cult magic, old world firearms, and fantastic art direction. 

Gameplay comprises navigating a different set of levels, avoiding and eviscerating enemies as you search for the exit with a variety of guns. From the fast firing pistols to the awesome explosive Riveter, the weapon selection in the game has everything you'd expect from a Not-So-Quake clone. Each level is a unique experience, and feels distinctly different to the last, with a focus on replaying levels completed for locating unseen secret areas and beating the inhouse par time assigned to each level. 

The OST is worth mentioning, and suites the gameplay perfectly with it's unique selection of hard guitar and...atmospheric scratchings? I thought a bug was in my headphones at one point during a level. The music selection does help to build the atmosphere that is thankfully unhindered by intentionally low polygon graphics and low resolution textures; clearly a design choice by the DUSK team. The game isn't hindered by it's claims of retrofuturism; it does well to bring it's own spin on the genre.

With two episodes at the time of writing, an "Endless" mode for each, and the everpopular [strike]QUAKEWORLD[/strike] DUSKWORLD multiplayer, $20 is a fair price for the content provided.

DUSK does it's part to introduce a new generation of gamers to the fold that the 1990s had wrought. Great job, New Blood.

DUSK is a throwback to shooters of old, but unlike many of it's contemporaries, it's a genuinely refreshing and robust experience that has a lot of charm of it's own. From rusty shacks choked by forest to hellscapes infested with the unimaginable horrors that science hath wrought, it's an immersive and thick game that rivals the atmospheric storytelling of Unreal and beautifully elegant level design of Half-Life. [u] Everything [/u] in this game is handcrafted by a small team to pack in as much love as possible, almost to the point where's it's unbelievable to think that a team you could count on your hands developed what is quite possibly game of the year material. Highly replayable singleplayer experience, deeply exhilarating multiplayer, and overall design that won't quit, DUSK isn't only a game you'd probably be remiss to skip, but it's quite possibly THE first person shooter experience of the entire decade. 39249684.review:
I plan to further edit this review because I'm barely awake and I will likely make many mistakes while I write this.

Dusk is a fast paced shooter that is very reminiscent of older FPS titles such as Quake and Unreal Tournament. However, Dusk manages to differentiate itself while retaining that same old classic feeling from those games. Dusk has a cult setting, where you are mowing down cultists and their fellow entities. The game retails for $20 USD and contains 2 campaigns (with 1 on the way) with multiplayer. I have only played 1 campaign so far, so I can't really comment on the rest of the campaign. So far, Episode 1 started off a little rough in my opinion. I like to get straight to the action and mayhem so I can tear apart all my enemies limb from limb with my trusty shotgun in hand. However, you start off with a melee weapon to quickly get your hands on a pistol and shortly after a shotgun. The shotgun for the most part feels fine. However, I wish it was slightly more powerful as it felt a little weak sometimes. The biggest flaw of episode 1 for me is level design. There were several areas that I reached and killed all it's inhabitants. However, I would figure out I would later return and unlock a weapon behind a locked door. Due to the level's design, it seemed like I was supposed to fight some enemies from earlier with the new weapon. However, I already killed them and I didn't get to test it until the next level. Additionally, I felt like levels sometimes broke up the flow of the level at times. I wanted to be overwhelmed with enemies and constantly be on the move trying to mow down my opponents. Instead, I felt like I had "crumbs" of the  action I was hoping for. On top of that, sometimes items that I needed were in hidden areas that sometimes were quite difficult to find. The secret areas in this game are very well hidden. However, some stuff was difficult to find and I would get fairly confused. Multiplayer is a fun mode but currently is limited. However, based on the rest of the game I wouldn't be surprised to see more features and tweaks to multiplayer soon. 

Overall, this is a good experience if you want an old-school shooter game. It's worth the $20. 

Will expand on review eventually.

39249517.review:
DUSK is the only game I've given a shit about for the past year or two, and let me tell you, it was well worth the fucking wait.

The singleplayer campaign is a hell of a lot of fun, complete with hand crafted levels, all sorts of devious enemies to kill (and be killed by), and an aesthetic I can't get enough of. While certainly inspired by old school shooters like Quake, Blood, and the like, the game brings enough new school to the table to change things up quite a bit while still retaining elements I loved from the classics, like exploration, weapons with purpose and personality, and a shit load of baddies to kill.

The multiplayer is one of the most fun, chaotic experiences I've had with a game in years. If you're a fan of the AFPS genre, you'll definitely find a lot to love here. Personally, using the crossbow to murder people through walls and teleporters with a bit of prediction has probably been the most satisfying bit of multiplayer ingenuinity I've encountered in quite some time. Unlike predecessors like Quake and Q3A, the mechanics are very easy to learn and improve upon, while still difficult to completely master, what with the ludicrous amounts of speed, 100% air control, crouch slides, and the like. Even though there's much polishing to be done, I've already spent countless hours on the multiplayer, and I plan to spend thousands more fragging and getting fragged.

If you love old school shooters and are sick of the CoDs and Overwatchs, if you love supporting indies, if you love kickass soundtracks, or if you're into the occult, buy this fucking game. It is hands down the best game I've played in years, and the developer is amazing, pouring his blood, sweat, and tears into every bit he possibly can (not to mention the QA team and others involved that are spending countless hours on the MP portion of the game, as well as the SDK). This is twenty dollars extremely well spent. What are you fucking waiting for?! Go forth, and kill the intruder!

39249373.review:
Я, возможно, один из первых пользователей русскоязычного сегмента, который предзаказал эту игру. По причине раннего доступа и новизны игры, этот обзор будет скорее всего рекомендацией для всех интересующихся. 

Что такое DUSK? Все современные шутеры, не важно на сколько они близки к классике (те же новый Doom и Вульфенштейн) всё равно имеют элементы современтных тенденций.  DUSK же это игра созданная фанатом для фанатов. Фанатов классической концепции шутера от первого лица. Всё то что дали первый Дум и Квейк здесь возведенно в абсолют. Игра чисто созданна для веселья и удовольствия прохождение, при этом не лишена самоиронии. Сюжет клиширован, но не без этого по своему эпичен и мрачный. Игра затягивает с первых секунд - такой эффект был в серии Half-Life, благодаря превойденной атмосфере и погружению в мир. 

Геймплей здесь динамичный и быстрый, гибкие настройки почти всего и довольно объективные уровни сложности. Хотя, мне кахжеться что предпоследний уровень сложности надо сделать еще хардкорнее чем он есть (строго рекомендую играть на нём). Карты больши и разнообразны, с кучей секретов.  

Плюс открытая бета мультиплееера. Я не фанат мультиплеера в играх, но этот случай другой. Если вам надоели микротранзакции, дизбаланс, плохой сетевой код - тогда этот режим для вас. 

После финального релиза и полного прохождение игры эта рекомендация превратиться в полноценный обзор. А пока советую не проходить мимо этой игры. Настолько комфортно себя во время прохождения я никогда еще не чувствовал.

И да, не ходите в руины.

39249329.review:
Simply one of the best FPS games I've played in a long time. Genuinely one of the few 'retro' FPS out there that genuinely gets what makes those old FPS games great, without turning it into a damn wave shooter like Serious Sam or Painkiller, or completely avoiding level design. Episode 2 in particular is one of the best FPS levels sets possibly ever. The game actually manages to reach the same level as those top level FPS classics in a lot of respects. If Episode 3 is half as good as Episode 2 there's no way this game won't be a classic, and well worth your money. Even the game's Endless mode never seems to get old. It may look kinda bland at first but with the right settings (texture filtering off, pixelization on 3 or so, limited colour pallet on) it genuinely looks great, especially with the amazing visuals throughout the second episode.

Duskworld is also great. It's pretty early in development but it's just pure old multiplayer FPS fun, but with actual players of all skill levels, not just people who've played Quake for 20 years straight. Multiple 1-hit-kills and easy movement mechanics which let you go stupidly fast make the game go at a blistering pace in a good way. Duels feel fairly unique, with a lot of tension given by how quickly everything can turn around and weapons like the crossbow (which shoots through walls and kills a spawn health/armour player in one hit) give it some neat unique features. High pop FFA on the otherhand is absolute fucking chaos and it's glorious.

39249008.review:
[h1][i]"If you love to reminisce about a decade you never actually existed in, [b]this is your go to game.[/b]"[/i][/h1]

[b]DUSK[/b] is a more [i]refined[/i] mixture of all the games that inspired it. Rather than using the low-poly aesthetic in a shallow, superficial way as most “[i]retro inspired shooters[/i]” tend to do, DUSK is made with the mentality that technology has not improved since the 90s and gaming trends haven’t moved too far from games like Quake or Unreal (maybe Half-Life as well?).

For a game that I bought on a whim, only knowing surface information about it from various online sources, $20 isn’t asking too much for it. Constantly entertained, pumped from the amped music, unloading super shotgun blasts  into mobs  to the beat.

[i]From the look, feel and atmosphere, DUSK is a fun ride no matter how you play it, though it’s more fun to be [strike]strafe jump[/strike]“[b]Hup[/b]”-ing around the maps at absurd speeds.[/i]

39248854.review:
[h1][b]INTRODUCTION:[/b][/h1]
DUSK is a love letter to the 90's, hearkening back to Doom, Hexen, Heretic, Redneck Rampage, Quake, and Half-Life, while also bringing a lot more to the table. New Blood have taken an approach that many others have tried and failed in the past, and have blown all expectations out of the water with only the first two episodes and an early implementation of multiplayer.
I will start this review off by saying I have played days of both DUSK Episodes 1+2 and the multiplayer counterpart, DUSKWorld during the pre-purchase beta, along with the Dusk/New Blood community and developers, and will hopefully be playing much more, especially as more content is added and things are changed.

[h1][b]STORY:[/b][/h1]
You are a treasure-hunter, simply known as the Dusk Dude, searching for treasure in the mysterious backwoods of Pennsylvania, when you are captured by a group of mysterious, pointy-headed cultists with an affinity for chainsaws and a bad taste in their mouths. Hooked to a wooden pole, three burly masked men with chainsaws enter the dank basement you find yourself in. An ominous voice is heard, "Kill the Intruder.", the rest is on you. The story itself pulls heavily from Quake and Redneck Rampage especially, and does so brilliantly.

[h1][b]GAMEPLAY:[/b][/h1]
Fast-paced and always hostile, DUSK will have you pitted against a variety of enemies with a variety of weapons and skills on your side. Spin your weapons like an Old West badass. Do front and backflips with an unlocked Y-axis in the air. Throw sawblades and turn enemies into red mist. Fire green phallic crossbow bolts through walls. DUSK captures perfectly the old school FPS feel, while adding so much to the mix. Multiplayer, while in it's early phases, is quick action fun even in it's current state. Everything available to you in Single Player can play a role online. Dedicated servers are to be added soon, and much later in development mod support will be implemented as well, extending the longevity of the multiplayer component by quite a bit.

[h1][b]GRAPHICS:[/b][/h1]
The game is ugly, in a good way. Low-poly models and low-resolution textures, yet stylish and used very well in most cases. If you enjoyed Quake's visuals, you'll love DUSK's. Plenty of graphics options, including something like a dozen color filters, super low resolution modes, etc.

[h1][b]SOUND and MUSIC:[/b][/h1]
A banging rock soundtrack by Andrew Hulshult, the music we've come to expect from this sort of game. He's a talented individual, and is a perfect fit for DUSK with beautiful ambient tracks, and the drops that kick in during the intense ambushes DUSK has to offer. The sound design for both the enemies and weapons are just as great, with enemies being intimidating, weapons having a lot of feel and power to them, and sounds working as cues to tell you more about the situation. Play this game with sound and headphones on!

[h1][b]CONCLUSION:[/b][/h1]
I've attempted to avoid any big spoilers or anything, so there are so many more things to be had in the game. Thank you for reading, fuck the character limit on reviews.

39248818.review:
I preordered the game way back in August and have had the chance to play Episode 1 and 2 of the single player campaign as well as the first two endless arenas. So far I'm about 30 hours in and counting.

Simply put, this game is everything you could ever wish for from a retro FPS game. Not only does it capture the feel of games like Blood and classic DOOM and the movement of Quake (HUP HUP HUP), it builds upon them and makes its own beautiful thing out of it. 

Especially the atmosphere and the organic story-telling beyond the initial, rather simple premise make it interesting not only for FPS fans. What makes it even more impressive is that this was designed and coded by literally one guy - the biggest props to David Szymanski to make his childhood dream come true and make the FPS genre live again like it's 1996. 

By purchasing this, you don't only get an incredible game (with the final third episode and the last endless arena still in the works), you also support an indie dev who truly deserves it. So what are you waiting for, get it already!

DUSK is an incredibly polished love letter to a ton of classic games. Though its inspirations are very clear, it manages to feel unique and refreshing. The gameplay is lightning fast, skill based, and lethal - but doesn't tread on the atmosphere, which can be very eerie and foreboding. The levels are packed with secrets and neat areas which makes them rewarding and interesting to explore.

At the time of this review, there are two episodes. They are both pretty lengthy and absolutely worth replaying through (I'm sitting at 10+ hours of playtime but foresee myself coming back multiple times). A third episode is coming, and I'm certain that when it comes out, it will blow away my expectations just like episode 2 did.

It's obvious to me that the developers poured their hearts and souls into it, and it's a hell of a lot of fun as a result. This game is incredible. It reminds me of some of my favorite games, Doom and Quake. Like those games, I'm positive that DUSK will become something I pick up and beat twice a year. Could not recommend more.

39248313.review:
[b]tl;dr: This game is a ton of fun right now and has a lot to offer if you enjoy arena style shooters or have been feeling an itch for a good, single player, retro fps![/b]

[b][i][u]-I am going to avoid spoilers in this review / explanation-[/u][/i][/b]

[h1]A "Quick" Summary:[/h1]
[b][i](I'll go into more detail about most of these points later in the review)[/i][/b]
I'm loving everything about this game! I pre-ordered it a while back ([i]before[/i] early access) and have been playing the single and multiplayer as 2 separate games. Right now, there are 2 episodes, the multiplayer, and 2 endless arenas to play with. And episode 3 and endless arena 3 are on the way, so the game is not 100% complete, but still has plenty to play with as it stands ([i]I have 90 hours in it so far[/i]). With that being said, DUSK takes what made games like Quake and DOOM great and makes them its own. You can play it fast and kill everything, play it passive and let everything live, or slow it down and look for secrets (there is a lot of them). The levels feel great and look great and each offer something different while being simple enough to get through with sometimes having multiple ways to complete them. Some of these levels have a bit of a horror element to them as well leading to some pretty tense and scary moments. Movement is fast and the weapons feel great and are perfect for the game. Combat can be hectic at times, but everything feels fair. I highly recommend this game.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
The story [i]so far[/i] is: You play as "Dusk Dude", a treasure hunter captured by demonic cultists. You must escape and kill them all. [i]Simple[/i]. As you progress you discover some truths about what's really been going on.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
[b][i](for now I will just talk about the single player, as it is the main feature of DUSK, however, a lot of this applies to the multiplayer as well)[/i][/b]

[b][u]MOVEMENT:[/u][/b] DUSK plays how you want it to. It can be played very fast by use of bunny-hopping or explosive jumping, or taken slower for those who wish to do so. The important thing is that you are in control. You have complete freedom in your movement both on the ground and in the air. Having this freedom allows you to dodge enemy's and get around the levels as you please and feel good while doing it. 

[b][u]BASIC WEAPONS:[/u][/b] There are technically 10 weapons in this game, but one is a special melee weapon seldom used. The main 9 weapons are nothing too fancy, but are perfect for the setting and theme. They feel extremely responsive, sound great, and all serve a unique purpose. I won't go into these purposes too much as its better to learn from playing, but they are pretty much what you would expect of them. Pistols for small enemy's, shotguns for getting in your enemy's faces or for needing high damage, rifles for medium and long ranges, explosives for crowds or bosses and for jumping to hard to reach places, a special crossbow which can shoot through walls and allow the player to hover if shot down, and your trusty sickles for when you're in a pinch. The guns follow the retro trend of not needing to manually reload or worry about magazines and a very quick to switch to and use. 

[b][u]IMPROVISED WEAPONS:[/u][/b] In DUSK you can pick up most small objects in the game, and each of these objects can be thrown to do different damages depending on what they are. It makes for interesting fights and allows the player to save ammo if needed.

[b][u]PICKUPS:[/u][/b] There are various health, armor (armor is called "morale" in DUSK), ammo, weapons, and power-ups placed throughout each level. Some are clearly presented as you move through them and others are hidden to reward exploration. Enemy's can also drop small amounts of health, morale, and ammo as well. These pickups feel very well placed and provide a good reason to explore as you can obtain some weapons early in the game.

[b][u]COMBAT:[/u][/b] No crazy AI in this game. If they see you, they will chase you. Rushing into a room guns blazing is the way this game was made to be played!

[b][u]SOUNDTRACK:[/u][/b] Badass soundtrack that is dynamic on most levels. No complaints here. Most of the sound design feels very modern, while still having some old school-esque sounds throughout the game.

[h1]Multiplayer:[/h1]
The multiplayer is awesome, but it is an afterthought or an add-on to the single player and is still in fairly early stages. It is a standard arena style PvP setup with (at the time of this review) only 1 game mode, free for all. However, more game modes are planned (CTF, TDM,etc). To start, you NEED to be fast and have a basic understanding of DUSK's movement to do [i]well[/i] in it. Or else you are an easy target for everyone else. But, with that being said, the multiplayer has a low skill floor and high skill ceiling. Anyone can easily get a hang of the movement and weapons within an hour or 2 and can take those skills very far. It is an arena style fps done right!

[h1]Graphics and Aesthetics:[/h1]
I figured I would toss this in at the end as it shouldn't be a [i]major[/i] selling point in my opinion. But this game is very 90's. What you see in the screenshots is what you get. But don't let its graphics make your choice on this game, it is very tastefully used and is very much part of its charm. 

[h1]Future Features:[/h1]
There is still a lot to be added to DUSK during its time in and out of early access. A SDK is currently in the works with planned workshop support, more game modes and features for multiplayer, potential co-op after it leaves early access, and episode 3 are the main things to note. But I'm sure many other small features and tweaks will be added along the way.

And that's about it! I'm loving this game so far and am looking forward to episode 3 within the next couple of months! I don't want to talk about enemy types or specifics of the levels just yet as those are best experienced by playing the game and are potential spoilers. Maybe after episode 3 comes out and I can look at everything as a whole I will add a spoiler section and talk about those.

[b][i]-BTW, This game is probably not going to go on sale anytime soon (if AT ALL) as to avoid the "I'll pick it up when it's on sale" excuse. It will also always be $20 no matter how much more content is added. This is a dev choice that has been stated multiple times on their Discord as well as on their 2018 announcement: "Nope. $20 then, $20 now, $20 forever." I think it is very much worth the price for the time I got (and am still getting) out of it. I have gotten 90+ hours between the single and multiplayer (40 single, 50 multi). It miiiight go on sale eventually, but I would not count on it. If this game looks appealing to you, PICK IT UP!!-[/i][/b]

39464694.review:
Сейчас сюда набежит уйма старперов, которые в приступе ярости «опустят» этот обзор, так что сразу все объясню. Компании я прошел еще на тестовом лаунчере, дважды, каждую. В мультиплеере провел от силы 3 часа, 1 из которых мне удалось провести в игре, а не на загрузочном экране. Это мало, чтобы дать адекватный обзор, но он необходим к написанию. Скажем, что это просто «крик души»

«Видишь неткод … И я не вижу, а он есть.»

DUSK – шутер от первого лица, у которого удалось сохранить в себе механики таких игр как Quake и Doom. Проект, цепляющий своим неординарным саундтреком, депрессивной обстановкой, а так же чувством ностальгии у всех тех динозавров, что застали время зарождения жанра. 

На данный момент игра все еще находится в разработке, поэтому все ниже перечисленное относится исключительно к тому состоянию игры, в котором она находится на момент написания обзора. Из всего, что дает нам игра на данный момент можно выделить три режима, каждому из которых я уделю отдельное внимание:

• Компанию

• Выживание

• Мультиплеер

На данный момент в игре представлены 2 компании, однако к релизу должна подоспеть третья. Если быть кратким, то они довольно динамичны, интересны и порой страшны. Каждая из них отличается друг от друга не только названием, но и контентом. Их имена:

• The Foothills (I)

• The Facilities (II)

• The Nameless City (III)

Для тех, кто хочет немного подтянуть свои способности к выживанию есть характерный режим, в котором вам предстоит выжить бесконечно количество волн, с каждой из которых количество противников будет увеличиваться. Этот режим так же насчитывает 3 карты ,а именно:

• The Farm 

• The Factory

• The Cathedral

И вот мы подошли к самому трепетному моменту, к тому, что ждала вся фан база игры, а именно к мультиплееру. У меня были грандиозные планы на «DUSKWORLD», как у большинства моих друзей, однако именно тут компания «New Blood Interactive» допустила ошибку.

Все, что необходимо для старта успешного сетевого проекта, было у игры. Карты, оружие, кастомизация, однако нет самого необходимого – серверов. Я бы мог долго распинаться о мультиплеере, если бы смог в него нормально сыграть, ибо из своих 2 часов, проведенных в игре, только 40 я потратил на саму игру.

Очевидно, что игра находится в разработке. Очевидно, что тяжело продвинуть такой проект массам, когда на рынке Steam господствуют такие гиганты как PUBG, CSGO, DOTA2, однако это не должно было помешать команде разработчиков сделать хороший неткод. Сингл очень хорош, он дает игроку все те чувства, которые он ожидает, но он имеет свойство заканчиваться, именно поэтому я акцентирую такое внимание на мультиплеере. Ведь для нас всех Quake запомнился не как одиночная игра, а как культовый компетитив мультиплеер.

Я уважаю автора и все его рвение создать хороший продукт, однако не вижу результата, хоть и прошел уже как год с начала разработки. Проект определенно имеет амбиции, так же он интересен , но только на один вечер. По крайней мере, на этом этапе разработки, игра очень сыра и не стоит своих денег. Прошу адекватно принять этот обзор, ибо ничто кроме как критического мышления, не способно продвигать этот проект.

DUSK stands on its own. I'm highly anticipating episode 3. I strongly recommend it.

39431464.review:
Quake, DooM, Tight, Gore, Metal, Blood (One Unit Whole), Jumping, Heretic, Guns, You can do a flip?!?! ...Did I miss anything?

Not only is the gameplay tight, twitchy and endlessly satisfying (did I mention you can do flips in mid-air?), not only are the maps expertly crafted full of rewarding secrets with just the right balance of mazes and open areas, not only is the soundtrack hype as hell and the visual design of the game nostalgic yet distinct... But also the settings menu is actually amazing and has all sorts of options for visual filters and video adjustment.

After blasting through the first episode I already feel like I've gotten my money's worth in a game that feels like a full and faithful follow-up to classic 90s FPS while still very much being a beast of its own. The guns are varied and feel great, the environments are rusty yet evocative, and the enemies are the perfect kind of shotgun-fodder. If you've been looking for a classic FPS to dive into but have already beaten many of them, this is the game for you.

For the uninitiated who may not be familiar with the aforementioned classic FPS, this actually may still be of a lot of interest! While you'll lose the nostalgia and may have to get used to the faster pace of these kinds of games, DUSK feels like the very best of what a 90s twitch shooter can be all hybrided into one. It draws from DooM's level design, Quake's tight and fast play, Rise of the Triad's jump-pads, and Blood's... well you know. All the while DUSK still stands as its own game, bringing new tricks, new weapons, and a treasure trove of extra features (And really doing a barrel roll in mid-air never gets old).

Now this is usually the part where I say "this is an early access game so you may want to wait..." But honestly, the single player is already so tight and (seemingly) complete I sincerely recommend buying this game early and diving into the frenzy of carnage and gunfire it has to offer!

Just buy Dusk.  I'm a massive fan of old school shooters, and Dusk is another reason why I still am. In a world full of uninteresting, boring Triple AAA titles, it's no surprise that the first game I've looked forward to in years was Dusk, and I'm loving every bit of this game.

Fast, frantic, old school shooting action at it's finest. Comes with 2 Episodes (3rd one coming soon), Endless Arena mode, and Duskworld. 

And Duskworld is insane. Some of the most fun, badass, and frantic multiplayer I've ever played. And this is coming from a guy who has been playing games like Quakeworld, Quake III, Unreal, and Tribes for years. 

But the best thing about all of it is that Dusk is genuine. This isn't just some "retro", throwback indie shooter. This is a game made with heart and soul. As one reviewer summed it up perfectly: "Dusk is what Strafe wanted to be."

39522647.review: An FPS that lets you bunnyhop up to the speed of a horse while dodging projectile based attacks from enemies in levels that find a happy medium between the exploratory and linear design philosophies of classic and modern shooters. You don't get lost but you don't get railroaded. The enemies and weapons are varied such that you get into a rhythm of selecting the right combinations of gun for the job instead of falling back on the same one or two weapons the whole game. It's a great FPS both for those who still dig into new Doom II WADs and those who want to see what this genre could do in 20th century.

39522641.review:
Estaba esperando obtener este juego desde que vi el primer trailer, con ese frenetismo y accion que solo daban juegos antiguos como Doom o Blood.

Pero Dusk es eso, y mucho mas. Cada episodio se siente como una minihistoria y ambientancion distintiva. El primero siendo mas libre con escenarios de ciudades, granjas y mostrandote la historia de un culto. El segundo se siente como si estubieras en un ambiente opresivo, industrias cerradas que me recuerdan a la que se sienten en half life o deus ex. Como veo el tercero tendra un ambiente mas demoniaco. Ademas que cada nivel se siente diferente, te enseña cosas nuevas, o te encuentras cada vez secretos mas rebuscados (busquen el de E1M2 y le dara una risa entera) que te dan ganas de seguir rejugando hasta tenerlo al 100%

Pero no solo es ambientacion, si no como se siente jugarlo, desde el primer nivel empiezas enfrentadote a unos de los enemigos mas comunes, y puedes sufrir algunas muertes si te esperas que sea algo sencillo. Aqui cada enemigo te castigara en su especialidad. Pero luego de aprender como atacan, o que mejor manera de enfretarlos hacer, se vuelve un juego de baile de balas. La velocidad con la que te mueves aunque alta, es muy fluida, asi que cada disparo, salto, cohetazo, o explosion que aciertes, te dara una sensacion de que estas haciendo mejor en este juego cada vez.

Cada arma cumple su proposito, y siento que al igual que Quake, siempre hay una que mejora a otra (Escopeta Doble Cañon > Escopeta de bombeo o Rifle de Asalto > Pistolas ) pero cada una trae sus desventaja y ventaja que siempre hay una razon para alternar entre ellas.

La musica esta acertada, entre musica opresiva que te trata de apresar y pensar que haras  y rock metalico cuando sabes que esto se pondra violento y explosivo. Un gran trabajo de Andrew, que tambien hizo algunos covers de canciones como la mayoria de Doom, recomiendo verlo.

El multiplayer, aunque acertado, aun tiene algunas fallas para internet lenta, pero se entiende aun estando en beta y se le dara un trabajo, con buena conexion, es como si Quake 1 y Quake 3 hicieran el amor con un poco de Doom, es rapido, frenetico, y con necesidad de saber donde esta cada arma y item para ayudarte, espero que se agregen modos de juego como CTF o Clan Arena para darle un mejor sabor.

PD: Busquen el jabon, es la cosa mas OP que he visto.

39521883.review:
Gran juego estilo retro, trayéndonos de vuelta el clásico QUAKE con su estilo de jugabilidad y un único y clásico modo historia en el que lo que tienes que hacer es matar, matar y matar pero tambien puedes hacer los niveles a lo speed run, pacifista y 100% encontrando todos los secretos y matando a todos los enemigos.

Habrá 3 episodios de historia en total, 2 por ahora. Estos se hacen bastante largos y realmente dan ganas de jugarlos de nuevo una vez te los pasas. La variedad de enemigos es enorme y, además, esta cambia en los differentes episodios sin apartarse de los enemigos más comunes. Cada nivel es enorme y con muchos escondrijos que explorar.

Hay 10 armas en total, cada una única de por sí y todas muy cómodas de utilizar y también son diferentemente eficaces dependiendo a qué enemigo disparas.

El juego también trae un modo multijugador clásico y entretenido. De momento solo tenemos los modos todos contra todos y duelo 1v1, pero veremos más en el futuro.

Recomiendo este juego al 100% si te gustan los clasicazos :D

39521821.review:
I'm not a longtime FPS fan like the people who played Doom and Quake back in the old days, but I watched gameplay videos of those games several years ago and knew for myself how retro those games are. I became a true old school FPS lover since the day I began playing Serious Sam almost three years ago. 

When I first discovered DUSK, I was very excited and intrigued. This reminded me of Quake mainly in terms of visuals (Like I mentioned a bit ago, I have watched a lot of Quake videos several years ago). Can I also say that I have dreams in my sleep about actually being an old school FPS protagonist? Anyway, months before I got my hands on DUSK, I played STRAFE, another first person shooter game with retro gameplay and visuals. Unfortunately, it turned out to be a major disappointment due to procedural generation, rougelike mechanics, and depressingly weak weapons. DUSK, on the other hand, doesn't have those problems.

Now, onto the game itself. On my first playthrough of Episode 1, I was quickly amazed by how superb the execution was. The environments are great in detail, movement is very fluid, and the weapons were great. This game, to me, is everything that STRAFE was not. Heck, you can even change the game settings to make it as retro as you feel like (Looks visually better without bilinear filtering, in my opinion).

DUSKWorld multiplayer was very superb as well, although I did get some lag from time to time. Like in the older FPS games, you can choose and name your character. In short, go find or create a server, hook up with some people, and start hupping and fragging.

I can't seem to find anything to complain about, other than the fact that DuskDude, as the community calls him, doesn't have a character and backstory of his. I would like to maybe learn more about him someday.

That's all I have to say for DUSK. After replaying the first and second episodes, I am fully ready for the third and final episode of the main game. I thank Dave and New Blood Interactive for bringing this game to life, and I would be very sad if I've never known about this game at all.

39466247.review:
Если честно, то не интересная игра. Итересно первые 4-5 уровней, когда [b]главный обман игры[/b] ещё не раскрылся: кажется, что перед тобой собрано всё лучшее из Doom или, вернее Doom 2 \ Quake 2, Redneck Rampage вкупе с Serious Sam и Painkiller.

А на деле получается весьма посредственный ретро-боевик, который очень скоро утомляет. Действительно, у Dusk сумасшедшие скорости, но это всё равно не спасает от скуки. На уровне от 30 до 80 мобов, которые даются строго дозировано по триггеру, плюс некоторые из них неоправданно "толстые" и портят всю динамику. Плюс типа дань уважения классике - поиск ключей, который на деле просто показывает логическую эволюцию игр из 90-х до наших дней - распрыжкой носиться по уровню только потому, что ты пропустил желтый ключ - ну такое.

Хотя вторая глава уже радует каким-то простором и более продуманной механникой сражений, но после первой главы возвращаться к игре уже как то и не тянет. 

Очень жалко, но однозначно советовать Dusk я не могу. Лучше навернуть Brutal Doom.
